page.title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{Redirect|13 Hours (film)|the 2010 British film|13Hrs}} {{for|the 2014 book on which the film is based|13 Hours (book)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = 13 Hours:
The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi | image = 13 Hours poster.png | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Michael Bay]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Michael Bay * [[Erwin Stoff]] }} | screenplay = [[Chuck Hogan]] | based on = {{based on|''[[13 Hours (book)|13 Hours]]''|[[Mitchell Zuckoff]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[James Badge Dale]] * [[John Krasinski]] * [[David Giuntoli]] * [[Max Martini]] * [[Pablo Schreiber]] * [[Toby Stephens]] * [[David Denman]] * [[Dominic Fumusa]] }} | music = [[Lorne Balfe]] | cinematography = [[Dion Beebe]] | editing = {{Plainlist| * [[Pietro Scalia]] * [[Michael McCusker]] * Calvin Wimmer }} | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2016|01|12|[[AT&T Stadium]]|2016|01|15|United States}} | runtime = 144 minutes{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/13-hours-secret-soldiers-benghazi-film | title=''13 HOURS: THE SECRET SOLDIERS OF BENGHAZI'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=January 19, 2016 | accessdate=January 19, 2016}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $50 million | gross = $69.4 million{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=13hoursthesecretsoldiersofbenghazi.htm|title=''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi'' (2016) |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=June 3, 2017}} | border = no | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[3 Arts Entertainment]] * Bay Films }} }} '''''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi''''' (also known simply as '''''13 Hours''''') is a 2016 American [[biographical film|biographical]] [[war film]] directed and produced by [[Michael Bay]] and written by [[Chuck Hogan]], based on [[Mitchell Zuckoff]]'s [[13 Hours (book)|2014 book of the same name]]. The film follows six members of Annex Security Team who fought to defend the American diplomatic compound in [[Benghazi]], [[Libya]] after waves of [[2012 Benghazi attack|attacks by militants on September 11, 2012]]. The film stars [[James Badge Dale]], [[John Krasinski]], [[David Giuntoli]], [[Max Martini]], [[Pablo Schreiber]] and [[Toby Stephens]]. Filming began on April 27, 2015 in [[Malta]] and [[Morocco]]. Known colloquially as "the Benghazi movie",{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/15/13-hours-michael-bay-benghazi-movie-the-american-way|title=13 Hours: Michael Bay's Benghazi movie and 'the American Way'|last=Schilling|first=Dave|date=January 15, 2016|website=The Guardian|language=|access-date=April 10, 2018}} the film was released on January 15, 2016, by [[Paramount Pictures]]. Upon release, ''13 Hours'' received generally mixed reviews from critics and grossed just $69 million worldwide against a budget of $50 million, becoming Bay's lowest-grossing film to date. The film received an [[Academy Award]] nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Sound Mixing|Best Sound Mixing]] at the [[89th Academy Awards]].{{cite web |last1= Calvario |first1=Liz |url= http://deadline.com/2017/02/13-hours-academy-rescinds-sound-mixing-nomination-greg-p-russell-1201989100/ |title= Academy Rescinds Sound Mixing Nomination for Greg P. Russell of ‘13 Hours’ |work= [[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=February 25, 2017 |accessdate=February 25, 2017}} == Plot == {{See also|2012 Benghazi attack}} In 2012, [[Benghazi]], [[Libya]] is named one of the most dangerous places in the world, and countries have pulled their diplomatic offices out of the country in fear of an attack by militants. The [[United States]], however, still has a diplomatic compound (not an official consulate) open in the city. Less than a mile away is a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] outpost called "The Annex", which is protected by a team of [[Private military company|private military contractors]] from [[Global Response Staff]] (GRS). New to the detail is Jack Silva, who arrives in Benghazi and is picked up by [[Tyrone S. Woods|Tyrone "Rone" Woods]], commander of the GRS team and a personal friend of Silva. Arriving at the Annex, Silva is introduced to the rest of the GRS team and the CIA [[Chief of Station]], who constantly gives the team strict reminders to never engage the citizens. The [[U.S. Ambassador to Libya|U.S. Ambassador]] [[J. Christopher Stevens|Chris Stevens]] arrives in Benghazi to maintain diplomatic connections amidst the political and social chaos. Despite warnings, Stevens decides to stay at the [[Special Mission Unit|Special Mission]] with limited protection from five [[Diplomatic Security Service|Diplomatic Security]] (DS) agents, principally, Scott Wickland and Dave Ubben, along with guards hired from the local [[February 17th Martyrs Brigade]] militia, nicknamed "17-Feb". On the morning of the eleventh anniversary of the [[September 11 attacks]], Stevens notices suspicious men taking pictures of the compound and notifies his security detail. Back at the Annex, Silva finds out that his wife is pregnant. That night, a group of militants from [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]] assault the compound. The 17-Feb guards quickly surrender their posts, allowing the attackers easy access to the Special Mission compound. Wickland takes Stevens and [[Sean Smith (diplomat)|Smith]], an IT specialist, into the safe room. Unable to breach the safe room, the attackers set the building on fire hoping to burn the men out. Wickland is able to escape but loses both Stevens and Smith. At the Annex, the GRS team desperately wants to go to the compound to help, but the Chief refuses, fearing that the team's departure would expose the Annex. However, the team dispatches to the compound and meets up with the DS agents. Silva and Woods go into the building to try to find Stevens and Smith, but are only able to find Smith's body. The DS team from the compound retreats to the Annex; but after Wickland goes in the wrong direction, they are followed back to the Annex. Later, the GRS team also retreats to the Annex. Knowing an attack by the militants is imminent, the CIA staff of the Annex makes several desperate calls for help. The only help they can get is from [[Glen Doherty|Glen "Bub" Doherty]], a GRS officer in [[Tripoli]], who forms a team including two [[Delta Force|Delta]] operators that fly to Benghazi after several delays. Meanwhile, the GRS team fends off the militants as they try to breach the Annex perimeter. After repelling the largest attack wave, the Annex receives word from [[Intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance|ISR]] that help is en route. The Tripoli GRS reinforcements arrive and begin preparing the CIA and DS staff to depart for the airport. The militants launch a mortar attack in which Ubben and Geist are wounded; Geist's left arm is partially severed. Woods rushes to aid Geist and is killed by another mortar round. Doherty is also killed when a third mortar detonates directly in front of him. With the GRS team compromised, and the Annex now vulnerable, the remaining GRS operators watch as a convoy of vehicles rolls toward the Annex. Fearing the worst, the operators prepare to make a final stand, until it is revealed that the convoy is an element of the [[Libya Shield Force]] militia escorting the GRS reinforcements. They also find out that Stevens was found behind the compound, but was pronounced dead at the hospital. At the airport, the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] staff and the wounded Geist board the plane to Tripoli while the remainder of the GRS team waits for the next plane with the bodies of Stevens, Smith, Woods and Doherty. Closing titles reveal that all of the surviving members of the Annex security team received contractor medals in a private ceremony and have since retired from the GRS team and live with their families (Geist was able to save his arm after several surgeries). == Cast == * [[James Badge Dale]] as [[American fatalities and injuries of the 2012 Benghazi attack#Tyrone S. Woods|Tyrone S. "Rone" Woods]], commander of the GRS team and former [[United States Navy SEALs|U.S. Navy SEAL]]. * [[John Krasinski]] as Jack Silva, newest member of the GRS team and former U.S. Navy SEAL.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/429812/13-hours-benghazi-fictionalized |title=Benghazi as Zombieland |publisher=National Review |date=January 15, 2016}} * [[Max Martini]] as Mark "Oz" Geist, GRS team member and former [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine]]. * [[Dominic Fumusa]] as John "Tig" Tiegen, GRS team member and former U.S. Marine. * [[Pablo Schreiber]] as [[Kris Paronto|Kris "Tanto" Paronto]], GRS team member and former [[U.S. Army Ranger]]. * [[David Denman]] as Dave "Boon" Benton, GRS team member and former U.S. Marine, a scout sniper. * [[Matt Letscher]] as Ambassador [[J. Christopher Stevens]]{{cite web|title=Matt Letscher|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0504762/|publisher=IMDB}} * [[Toby Stephens]] as [[American fatalities and injuries of the 2012 Benghazi attack#Glen Doherty|Glen "Bub" Doherty]], GRS officer in Tripoli and good friend of Tyrone Snowden "Rone" Woods * [[Alexia Barlier]] as Sona Jillani, an undercover CIA officer in Libya. * [[Freddie Stroma]] as Brit Vayner, an undercover CIA officer in Libya * [[David Costabile]] as "Bob" aka. "The Chief", the Benghazi CIA Chief-of-Station. * [[Peyman Moaadi]] as Amahl, a local interpreter. * [[David Giuntoli]] as Scott Wickland, [[Diplomatic Security Service|DSS]] agent. * [[Demetrius Grosse]] as Dave Ubben, [[Diplomatic Security Service|DSS]] agent. * [[David Furr]] as Alec, [[Diplomatic Security Service|DSS]] agent. * Christopher Dingli as [[Sean Smith (diplomat)|Sean Smith]], IT specialist. * [[Davide Tucci]] as [[Defence Attache|Defence Attaché]] * Shane Rowe as CIA Annex Cook, who participates in the defense of the Annex. * Gábor Bodis as CIA agent, security officer * [[Wrenn Schmidt]] as Becky Silva, wife of Jack Silva == Production == === Development === On February 10, 2014, it was announced that [[Paramount Pictures]] was in talks with 3 Arts Entertainment to acquire the film rights to the book ''[[13 Hours (book)|13 Hours]]'', written by [[Mitchell Zuckoff]], with [[Erwin Stoff]] to produce.{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Mike, Jr.|title=Paramount In Talks For Benghazi Attack Film Based On Book By Survivors|url=http://deadline.com/2014/02/paramount-in-talks-for-benghazi-attack-film-based-on-book-by-survivors-680448/|accessdate=May 4, 2015|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=February 10, 2014}} [[Chuck Hogan]] was set to adapt the book, based on the true events of the [[2012 Benghazi attack|Benghazi attack]] by militants on the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, on the evening of September 11, 2012. The film would focus on six members of a security team that fought to defend the Americans stationed there. On October 29, 2014, [[Michael Bay]] was set to direct and produce the thriller.{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Michael Bay in Talks to Direct Benghazi Movie '13 Hours' (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/michael-bay-talks-direct-benghazi-744933|accessdate=May 4, 2015|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 29, 2014}} === Casting === On January 14, 2015, [[John Krasinski]] was cast in the film, to play one of the lead roles, a former [[United States Navy SEALs|US Navy SEAL]].{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=John Krasinski to Star in Michael Bay's Benghazi Movie '13 Hours'|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/john-krasinski-13-hours-casting-michael-bay-1201372268/|accessdate=January 15, 2015|publisher=variety.com|date=January 14, 2015}} On February 3, [[Pablo Schreiber]] also signed on to star in the film, playing Kris "Tanto" Paronto, one of the six-man security team.{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title='Orange is the New Black' Actor Pablo Schreiber Joins Michael Bay's '13 Hours' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/orange-is-the-new-black-actor-pablo-schreiber-joins-michael-bays-13-hours-exclusive-1201422957/|accessdate=February 5, 2015|publisher=variety.com|date=February 3, 2015}} On February 6, [[James Badge Dale]] was set to star, as the leader of the security team.{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr|first1=Mike|title=James Badge Dale Lands Lead In Michael Bay Benghazi Project '13 Hours'|url=http://deadline.com/2015/02/james-badge-dale-michael-bay-benghazi-1201367580/|accessdate=February 7, 2015|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=February 6, 2015}} [[Max Martini]] was cast as another member of the security team on February 17, 2015.{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title='Pacific Rim' Actor Max Martini Joins Michael Bay's '13 Hours' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/pacific-rim-actor-max-martini-joins-michael-bays-13-hours-exclusive-1201435244/|accessdate=April 4, 2015|publisher=variety.com|date=February 17, 2015}} [[David Denman]] signed on to star in the film on March 3, 2015, playing Boon, an elite sniper.{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Michael Bay's '13 Hours' Finds Its Sniper in 'The Office' Actor (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/michael-bays-13-hours-finds-778913|accessdate=April 4, 2015|work=hollywoodreporter.com|date=March 3, 2015}} On March 5, 2015, ''THR'' reported that [[Dominic Fumusa]] also signed on, to play John "Tig" Tiegen, one of the members of the security team, who is also a former Marine with weapons expertise.{{cite news|last1=Ford|first1=Rebecca|title=Michael Bay's '13 Hours' Adds 'Nurse Jackie' Actor Dominic Fumusa (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/michael-bays-13-hours-adds-779590|accessdate=May 4, 2015|work=hollywoodreporter.com|date=March 5, 2015}} [[Freddie Stroma]] was added to the cast on March 17, 2015 to play the role of an undercover CIA officer in Libya.{{cite news|last1=Pedersen|first1=Erik|title=Freddie Stroma Has '13 Hours'; Christopher Gorham Lands Lead In 'Po'; 'Exeter' Set For DirecTV Bow|url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/freddie-stroma-has-13-hours-christopher-gorham-lands-lead-in-po-exeter-set-for-directv-bow-1201394073/|accessdate=May 10, 2015|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=March 17, 2015}} On May 7, 2015, [[Toby Stephens]] was set to play Glen "Bub" Doherty, another of the security team members.{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title='Black Sails' Actor Toby Stephens Joins Michael Bay's '13 Hours' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/toby-stephens-13-hours-cast-michael-bay-black-sails-1201490271/|accessdate=May 10, 2015|work=variety.com|date=May 7, 2015}} === Filming === [[Principal photography]] began on April 27, 2015 in [[Malta]] and [[Morocco]].{{cite news|title=On the Set for 4/27/15: Jennifer Lawrence Wraps David O. Russell's Joy & Starts on X-Men: Apocalypse|url=http://www.ssninsider.com/on-the-set-for-42715-jennifer-lawrence-wraps-david-o-russells-joy-starts-on-x-men-apocalypse/|accessdate=April 27, 2015|work=ssninsider.com|date=April 27, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518095836/http://www.ssninsider.com/on-the-set-for-42715-jennifer-lawrence-wraps-david-o-russells-joy-starts-on-x-men-apocalypse/|archive-date=May 18, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} A large film set was built in March 2015 in [[Ta' Qali]], Malta.{{cite news|last1=Schembri Orland|first1=Kevin|title=13 Hours: Michael Bay film set built near Flower Power|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2015-03-30/local-news/13-Hours-Michael-Bay-film-set-built-near-Flower-Power-6736132995|accessdate=May 10, 2015|work=independent.com.mt|date=March 30, 2015}} == Release == On June 30, 2015, Paramount announced that the new title would be ''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi'', and set the film to be released on January 15, 2016, on the [[MLK Day|MLK Holiday]] weekend.{{cite news|last1=A. Lincoln|first1=Ross|title=Paramount’s ’13 Hours’ Benghazi Drama Confirmed For MLK Weekend 2016|url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/benghazi-drama-13-hours-benghazi-drama-in-theaters-mlk-2016-1201464746/|accessdate=July 2, 2015|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=June 30, 2015}} The film premiered on January 12, 2016, at the [[AT&T Stadium]] in [[Arlington, Texas]],{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/06/movies/13-hours-gives-benghazi-attack-cinematic-treatment.html|title=‘13 Hours’ Gives Benghazi Attack Cinematic Treatment|first=Michael|last=Cieplyjan|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 5, 2016|accessdate=January 6, 2016}} benefitting the Shadow Warriors Project, which supports private military security personnel and other groups. Unusually for a major American film, the film was given only a [[limited release]] in Canada during its American wide opening weekend, playing in select theatres in [[Toronto]], [[Montreal]], [[Vancouver]], [[Edmonton]], [[Calgary]] and [[Ottawa]]. The film expanded to a [[wide release]] in Canadian theatres the following weekend, January 22–24.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribute.ca/movies/13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi/111435/|title=13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi|work=Tribute.ca}}{{cite web|url=http://filmjunk.com/2016/01/15/new-to-theatres-this-weekend-13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi-ride-along-2-norm-of-the-north/|title=New to Theatres This Weekend: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi, Ride Along 2, Norm of the North – Film Junk|publisher=}} Paramount specifically marketed the film to conservatives,{{Citation |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |date=January 15, 2016 |title= Benghazi attack film 13 Hours is marketed to conservative audiences |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/15/benghazi-attack-film-13-hours-targets-conservative-audiences |accessdate=January 24, 2016 }}{{cite web |url=http://thedailybanter.com/2016/01/quote-of-the-day-10/|title=Quote of the Day: Paramount Pictures Is Sad You Didn't See "13 Hours" Because You're Too Partisan |first=Chez |last=Pazienza |author-link=Chez Pazienza |work=The Daily Banter |date=January 17, 2016 |accessdate=January 24, 2016}} in a method similar to previous films ''Lone Survivor'' and ''American Sniper'', both of which had beaten box office expectations.{{cite web |url=http://thedailybanter.com/2016/01/the-cynical-marketing-of-13-hours-is-already-giving-conservatives-a-benghazigasm/ |title=The Cynical Marketing of "13 Hours" Is Already Giving Conservatives a Benghazigasm |first=Chez |last=Pazienza |work=The Daily Banter |date=January 6, 2016 |accessdate=January 24, 2016}} This included screening the film for key [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] figures in order to generate endorsement quotations.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/13-hours-box-office-michael-by-donald-trump-hillary-clinton-republicans-1201684874/|title='13 Hours' Opens Lower Than Expected; Being Politicized Didn't Help|first=Anthony |last=D'Alessandro |website=Deadline Hollywood |date=January 17, 2016 |accessdate=January 24, 2016}} === Home media === ''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Benghazi'' was released on DVD and Blu-ray on June 7, 2016. Likely due to a boost from the [[2016 U.S. Presidential Election]], the film made $40 million in DVD and Blu-ray sales by August 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2016/08/05/michael-bays-13-hours-gets-huge-sales-boost-as-election-nears.html |title=Michael Bay's '13 Hours' gets huge sales boost as election nears |publisher=[[Fox News]] |date= |accessdate=January 28, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/michael-bays-benghazi-film-gets-916588 |title=Michael Bay's Benghazi Film Gets Trump Bump in Home Video}} == Reception == === Box office === ''13 Hours'' grossed $52.9 million in North America and $16.5 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $69.4 million, against a production budget of $50 million, making it Michael Bay's lowest-grossing directorial film to date.{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Director&id=michaelbay.htm | title=Michael Bay Movie Box Office Results | website=Box Office Mojo | accessdate=April 7, 2016}} The film was projected to earn around $20 million in its four-day Martin Luther King weekend debut. It faced competition from fellow newcomer ''[[Ride Along 2]]'', as well as holdovers ''[[The Revenant (2015 film)|The Revenant]]'' and ''[[Star Wars: The Force Awakens]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-movie-projector-20160113-story.html|title='Ride Along 2' is likely to take over No. 1 spot at box office this weekend|first=Ryan|last=Faughnder|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=January 13, 2016|accessdate=January 13, 2016}} Other films in a similar vein that had opened on the MLK weekend in previous years, ''[[American Sniper]]'' ($107.2 million in 2015) and ''[[Lone Survivor (film)|Lone Survivor]]'' ($37.8 million in 2014), found success, although they had faced weaker competition, and were considered less politically divisive.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-preview-13-hours-855167|title=Box-Office Preview: Michael Bay's Benghazi Movie '13 Hours' Could Be Politically Divisive|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 12, 2016|accessdate=January 13, 2016}} However, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' noted that the film could outperform expectations if it was buoyed by waves of patriotism. The film made $900,000 from 1,995 theaters during its Thursday previews and $16.2 million in its opening weekend, finishing fourth at the box office.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/ride-along-2-begins-to-zoom-in-thursday-previews-box-office-1201683644/ |title= ‘Ride Along 2’ & ‘Revenant’ Pushing ‘Star Wars’ To 3rd Place Over 4-Day MLK Holiday; Kevin Hart-Ice Cube Sequel Eyes $40.2M |work= deadline.com}} === Critical response === ''13 Hours'' received mixed reviews from critics, though some viewed it as a welcomed tame effort from Michael Bay.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi-review-dramatized-look-at-the-deadly-2012-benghazi-attack-1.11328669|title=‘13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi’ review: Dramatized look at the deadly 2012 Benghazi attack|first=Rafer|last=Guzmán|work=Newsday}}{{cite web | url =http://www.cinemalogue.com/2016/01/15/13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi/ | title =13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi | last1 = Jorgenson | first1 =Todd | author-link1 = | last2 = | first2 = | author-link2 = | date =January 16, 2016 | year = | website =Cinemalogue.com | publisher = | access-date =January 18, 2016 | subscription = }}{{cite web|url=http://theyoungfolks.com/review/13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi-michael-bay/70719|title=Movie Review: '13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi' – The Young Folks|work=The Young Folks}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fatguysatthemovies.com/13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi-movie-review/|title=Fat Guys at the Movies - ’13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi’ Movie Review|work=Fat Guys at the Movies}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tri-cityherald.com/entertainment/movies-news-reviews/mr-movie/article54596165.html|title=Mr. Movie|work=tri-cityherald}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 50% based on 210 reviews, with an [[average rating]] of 5.5/10 against an audience approval rating of 82%. The site's consensus reads, "''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi'' is a comparatively mature and restrained effort from Michael Bay, albeit one that can't quite boast the impact its fact-based story deserves."{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/13_hours_the_secret_soldiers_of_benghazi/ |title=''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi'' (2016) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] |accessdate=March 12, 2016}} On [[Metacritic]] the film has a score of 48 out of 100, based on 36 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi |title=''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi'' Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=January 21, 2016}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web|url=https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CY0f1EJUAAAeatD.png |title=CinemaScore |publisher=cinemascore.com |via=[[Twitter]]}} Soren Andersen, writing for ''[[The Seattle Times]]'', gave the film 3 stars out of 4, criticizing the lack of distinctive characters but ultimately summarizing ''13 Hours'' as "engrossing" and "a ground-level depiction of heroism in the midst of the fog of war".{{cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/movies/13-hours-a-gripping-look-at-what-happened-in-benghazi/?|title=13 Hours: a gripping look at what happened in Benghazi|first=Soren|last=Andersen|work=[[Seattle Times]]|date=January 14, 2016|accessdate=January 14, 2016}} [[Richard Roeper]] similarly praised ''13 Hours'' in his review for the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''. Although he lamented the script, Roeper found the film to be a "solid action thriller with well-choreographed battle sequences and strong work from the ensemble cast".{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.suntimes.com/entertainment/post/13-hours-secret-soldiers-benghazi-michael-bay-keeps-focus-fight-fighters/|title=’13 HOURS: THE SECRET SOLDIERS OF BENGHAZI': MICHAEL BAY KEEPS FOCUS ON FIGHT AND FIGHTERS|author=[[Richard Roeper]]|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=January 14, 2016|accessdate=January 14, 2016}} Like Roeper's review, ''[[New York Daily News]]''{{'}} Joe Dziemianowicz was less receptive towards the script, but applauded the film's focus on the real-life attack, summarizing: "War is gritty here, not glamorous... [[[Michael Bay]]] delivers a gripping, harrowing, and heartfelt film."{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/movies/michael-bay-13-hours-gripping-benghazi-story-article-1.2495477|title=Movie review: Michael Bay's ‘13 Hours’ is a gripping Benghazi story with a ripped John Krasinski|first=Joe|last=Dziemianowicz|work=[[New York Daily News]]|date=January 13, 2016|accessdate=January 14, 2016}} In a mixed review, Inkoo Kang of [[TheWrap]] praised ''13 Hours'' for its action scenes, but panned Bay's direction as "myopic". She writes, "''13 Hours'' is the rare Michael Bay movie that wasn't made with teenage boys in mind. But that doesn't make his latest any less callously juvenile."{{cite web|url=https://www.thewrap.com/13-hours-review-john-krasinski-james-badge-dale-pablo-schreiber/|title=’13 Hours’ Review: Michael Bay's Benghazi Tale Has Way More Bullets Than Brains|first=Inkoo|last=Kang|website=[[TheWrap]]|date=January 13, 2016|accessdate=January 14, 2016}} Lindsey Bahr of the [[Associated Press]] was critical of the film's direction and cinematography, and found the screenplay to be confusing.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory/review-13-hours-thrilling-video-game-36279697|title=Review: '13 Hours' Is Thrilling, but Too Video Game-Like|first=Lindsey|last=Bahr|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=January 14, 2016}} Similarly, ''[[The Economist]]'' described the film as "a sleek, poorly scripted and largely meaningless film". === Libyan response === The film caused controversy in Libya.[https://nypost.com/2015/10/20/hollywood-benghazi-film-sparks-controversy-inside-libya/ Hollywood Benghazi film sparks controversy inside Libya] New York Post Many Libyans believed it ignored the contributions of local people who helped save the US ambassador.[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/oct/22/michael-bay-13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi-libyan-politicians-bloggers-criticism-social-media Angry Libyans slam Michael Bay's Benghazi attack thriller] The Guardian Libya's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Salah Belnaba, denounced the film's portrayal of the Libyan people and described it as "fanatical and ignorant."[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/hollywood-benghazi-film-sparking-anger-inside-libya/ Hollywood Benghazi film sparking anger inside Libya] CBS News Libya's Culture and Information Minister, Omar Gawaari, also criticized the film saying: "the movie shows the US contractors who actually failed to secure the ambassador ... as heroes", adding that Michael Bay “turned America’s failure to protect its own citizens in a fragile state into a typical action movie all about American heroism”.[http://www.bbc.com/arabic/artandculture/2015/10/151020_libya_film_controversy فيلم حول الهجوم على القنصلية الأمريكية في بنغازي يثير جدلا داخل ليبيا] BBC === Accolades === At the [[89th Academy Awards]], ''13 Hours'' received a nomination for [[Academy Award for Best Sound Mixing|Best Sound Mixing]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/jan/24/la-la-land-equals-record-for-most-oscar-nominations|title=La La Land equals record for most Oscar nominations|date=January 24, 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=January 24, 2017}} However, [[Greg P. Russell]] (one of the four nominees from the film) had his nomination rescinded when it was discovered that he had contacted voters for the award by telephone in violation of campaigning regulations. == Historical accuracy == The film's historical accuracy has been disputed. In the film's most controversial scene, the CIA chief in Benghazi (identified only as "Bob") tells the military contractors there, who seek permission to go defend the embassy, to "stand down", thus denying them permission. The real-life CIA chief stated that there was no stand-down order.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/movies/former-benghazi-cia-chief-slams-13-hours-secret-soldiers-benghazi-n497506|title=Former Benghazi CIA Chief Slams '13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi'|first=Corky|last=Siemaszko|publisher=NBC News| accessdate =January 17, 2016}} His statement was echoed by the bipartisan Senate Intelligence Committee's finding that there was "no evidence of intentional delay or obstruction by the Chief of Base or any other party".{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/1/15/10774928/13-hours-benghazi-michael-bay|title=Michael Bay's 13 Hours promotes some of the worst Benghazi conspiracy theories|first=Zack|last=Beauchamp|date=January 15, 2016|work=Vox| accessdate =January 17, 2016}} However, no help was sent, even though officials at the highest levels found out about the attack within the first few hours out of the 13. Also, ''[[National Review]]'' commentator [[David A. French|David French]] argues that the Senate committee cited above found plenty of evidence of the "stand down" order in the form of personal testimony from multiple witnesses. It just chose to rule that the contrary testimony outweighed it.{{cite web |title=13 Hours: Of Course There's Evidence of a ‘Stand-Down Order’ in Benghazi |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/429855/13-hours-yes-there-evidence-stand-down-order-benghazi |first=David |last=French |publisher=National Review |date=January 15, 2016}} Kris "Tanto" Paronto, a CIA contractor who was involved in action during the event said, "We were told to 'stand down'. Those words were used verbatim—100 percent. If the truth of it affects someone's political career? Well, I'm sorry. It happens."{{cite web|title = New Benghazi movie reignites ‘stand-down’ order debate|url = http://www.politico.com/story/2016/01/benghazi-movie-stand-down-order-debate-217622|website = POLITICO|accessdate = January 18, 2016}} The CIA base chief portrayed in the film has directly contradicted Paronto's claims, saying "There never was a stand-down order... At no time did I ever second-guess that the team would depart."{{cite web|last=Daly|first=Matthew|title=AP FACT CHECK: Benghazi movie misstates some facts|url=http://wtop.com/movies/2016/01/ap-fact-check-benghazi-movie-misstates-some-facts/|publisher=WTOP (Associated Press)|date=January 20, 2016|access-date=May 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415024226/http://wtop.com/movies/2016/01/ap-fact-check-benghazi-movie-misstates-some-facts/|archive-date=April 15, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Also disputed is the film's portrayal that air support was denied. A House Armed Services Committee report found that air support was unavailable, or it would have arrived too late to make a difference.{{cite news|author1=M.S.R.|title=Could a Hollywood film about Benghazi damage Clinton?|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2016/01/outstandown-nonsense-0|date=January 18, 2016|accessdate=January 19, 2016|work=[[The Economist]]}} French defended the film's references to air support, writing that even if resources could not have been flown in during the time available, this would itself be "scandalous", given Libya's known instability. In July 2016, the Republican-led House Select Committee on Benghazi released its report that included numerous witnesses indicating that U.S. military help was available, but not called upon. The report indicated the Department of Defense would not provide the requested list of military assets that were available that night.{{cite web |url=http://benghazi.house.gov/NewInfo |title=Select Committee on Benghazi Releases Proposed Report | Select Committee on Benghazi |publisher=Benghazi.house.gov |date= |accessdate=October 14, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161013190741/http://benghazi.house.gov/NewInfo |archive-date=October 13, 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The film also asserts that Ambassador Stevens didn't want additional security, but that is false.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=September 2018}} American conservative columnist [[Deroy Murdock]] wrote that the film confirmed his personal view that President [[Barack Obama]] and [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] were lying when they initially blamed the [[YouTube]] video ''[[Innocence of Muslims]]'' for the attacks in the weeks after they occurred. The video led to various [[reactions to Innocence of Muslims|protests among Muslims around the world]], and Obama and others initially stated publicly that the Benghazi attacks emerged from such a protest. Murdock noted that ''13 Hours'' instead portrays the attacks as having been initiated by "well-armed jihadists who know exactly what they are doing".{{cite web |title=13 Hours Confirms Obama's and Hillary Clinton's Lies about Benghazi |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/430080/13-hours-movie-benghazi-obama-hillary-clinton |first=Deroy |last=Murdock |work=National Review |date=January 21, 2016}} Some of the vehicles used in the movie are models from later years, especially the [[Mercedes-Benz G-Class]] (model year 2013) and the [[Mercedes-Benz C-Class (W205)]] (model year 2015) which did not exist when the attacks happened in 2012, only known to be original prototypes. == See also == {{Portal|Film}} * [[2012 Benghazi attack]] * [[Counterterrorism Center]] * [[List of films featuring the United States Navy SEALs]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Wikiquote}} * {{Official website|http://www.thirteenhoursmovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|4172430}} * {{Mojo title|13hoursthesecretsoldiersofbenghazi}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|13_hours_the_secret_soldiers_of_benghazi}} * {{Metacritic film|13-hours-the-secret-soldiers-of-benghazi}} * {{AllMovie title|638808}} (rating 3/5) * [http://www.historyvshollywood.com/reelfaces/13-hours/ ''13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi''] at ''[[History vs. Hollywood]]'' {{Michael Bay}} {{DEFAULTSORT:13 Hours The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi}} [[Category:2016 films]] [[Category:2010s action thriller films]] [[Category:2010s war films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American action thriller films]] [[Category:American war films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Action films based on actual events]] [[Category:Thriller films based on actual events]] [[Category:War films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films about terrorism]] [[Category:Films based on non-fiction books]] [[Category:Films directed by Michael Bay]] [[Category:Films scored by Lorne Balfe]] [[Category:2012 Benghazi attack]] [[Category:Films set in Libya]] [[Category:Films set in 2012]] [[Category:Films shot in Malta]] [[Category:Films shot in Morocco]] [[Category:Films about the United States Armed Forces]] [[Category:Films about Delta Force]] [[Category:Films about United States Navy SEALs]] [[Category:Paramount Pictures films]] [[Category:3 Arts Entertainment films]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} This article is a list of events taking place in 2016 related to [[Philippine television]]. {{Year nav topic5|2016|Philippine television}} {{TOC limit|3}}
==Events==
===January=== * January 1 ** [[Charo Santos-Concio]] retires as president and CEO of the [[ABS-CBN Corporation]] and is succeeded by its COO, [[Carlo Katigbak|Carlo L. Katigbak]], although she retains her role as chief content officer, president of ABS-CBN University, and executive adviser to the chairman [[Gabby Lopez]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burgonio|first1=Maricel|title=ABS-CBN appoints Carlo Katigbak as its new president, CEO|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/abs-cbn-appoints-carlo-katigbak-as-its-new-president-ceo/|accessdate=January 7, 2016|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]|date=December 18, 2015}}</ref> ** [[ABS-CBN Corporation]] launched their second [[high-definition television|high-definition]] cable channel, [[ABS-CBN Sports and Action|S+A]], replacing [[Balls (TV channel)|Balls HD]], on [[SkyCable|Sky Cable]], [[Destiny Cable]] and [[Sky Direct]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gasgonia|first1=Dennis|title=ABS-CBN launches new sports channel|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/sports/01/16/14/abs-cbn-launches-new-sports-channel|accessdate=January 7, 2016|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|date=January 4, 2016}}</ref> ** [[GMA Network (company)|GMA Network Inc.]] formally unveils the newest version of [[Lupang Hinirang]] (Philippine national anthem) aired during sign-on and sign-off of [[GMA Network|GMA]] and [[GMA News TV]] and the first screening and last full show of films in selected [[SM Supermalls|SM]] cinemas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/corporate/photos/2015-12-23/37/GMA-Networks-2015-production-of-Lupang-Hinirang/|title=GMA Network's 2015 production of 'Lupang Hinirang'|publisher=GMA Network|date=December 23, 2015|accessdate=January 1, 2016}}</ref> * January 7 – Streaming service [[Netflix]] finally launched on the Philippines as part of its biggest global expansion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Netflix arrives in the Philippines|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/lifestyle/gadget-and-tech/01/07/16/netflix-arrives-in-the-philippines|website=ABS-CBNNews.com|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News]]|accessdate=November 25, 2017|date=January 7, 2016}}</ref> * January 25 – President [[Benigno Aquino III]] approved the privatization plans of the government-sequestered television network [[Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation]] (IBC-13) thru public bidding.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/business/01/25/16/pnoy-oks-privatization-of-ibc-13|title=PNoy OKs privatization of IBC-13|publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News]]''|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gov.ph/2016/01/25/pres-aquino-approves-privatization-ibc-13/|title=President Aquino approves privatization of IBC-13|publisher=Official Gazette|date=January 25, 2016|accessdate=January 25, 2016}}</ref>
===February=== * February 1 – The [[ABS-CBN]] program ''[[On the Wings of Love (TV series)|On the Wings of Love]]'' apologizes to the [[Philippine National Police]] (PNP) on a complaint of using a police uniform on [[James Reid (entertainer)|James Reid]]'s character in a striptease scene with [[Nadine Lustre]]'s character in the January 11 episode of the drama series.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/121047-on-the-wings-of-love-otwol-police-uniform-controversy|title='On The Wings of Love' airs apology over police uniform controversy|publisher=''[[Rappler]]''|date=February 1, 2016|accessdate=February 1, 2016}}</ref> * [[GMA Network]]'s ''[[Wowowin]]'' returned to the airwaves now as a daily afternoon program. * February 7 – Lucky Aces was named the first grand winner of ''[[Dance Kids]]'' held at the Newport Performing Arts Theater at [[Resorts World Manila]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/121628-lucky-aces-dance-kids-winner | title= Lucky Aces win 'Dance Kids'|publisher= ''[[Rappler]]''|date=February 7, 2016 | accessdate=February 7, 2016}}</ref> * February 12 – The [[ABS-CBN]] program ''[[It's Showtime (variety show)|It's Showtime]]'' launched its all-female dance group known as the ''GirlTrends'' consisting of 21 talents from Star Magic, [[Pinoy Big Brother]] and other programs.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.chikka-nessavenue.com/2016/02/its-showtime-launches-all-female-group.html | title=It's Showtime Launches All-Female Group "Girl Trends" | publisher=''Chikkaness Avenue'' | date=February 12, 2016 | accessdate=February 12, 2016}}</ref> * February 21 – The [[PiliPinas Debates 2016 – Mindanao leg|first leg]] of the [[PiliPinas Debates 2016]], a COMELEC-organized presidential debate held at the [[Capitol University]], [[Cagayan de Oro]] and aired on [[GMA Network]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thestandard.com.ph/showbitz/199820/-pilipinas-debates-2016-today-on-gma-7.html|title=‘PiliPinas Debates 2016’ today on GMA 7|publisher=''The Standard''|date=February 20, 2016|accessdate=February 21, 2016}}</ref>
===March=== * March 1 – [[WWE Network]], a streaming service owned by [[WWE]], became available in the Philippines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/sports/by-sport/other-sports/124267-wwe-network-philippines|title=WWE Network now available in the Philippines|publisher=|accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> * March 15 – [[ABS-CBN News Channel]] was launched in [[high-definition television|high-definition]] as ANC HD on [[SkyCable|Sky Cable]] and [[Destiny Cable]]. It is the third high-definition cable channel of [[ABS-CBN|ABS-CBN Corporation]] after ABS-CBN HD and ABS-CBN Sports + Action HD. * March 16 – [[ABS-CBN|ABS-CBN Corporation]] forged a partnership with [[Viva Films]] and [[Regal Entertainment]] for the broadcast rights of their respective films in ABS-CBN's free-to-air networks, cable channels, video on demand, and global assets. At the same time, ABS-CBN also signed a deal with Artikulo Uno Productions for the broadcast rights of ''[[Heneral Luna]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=C|first=Ranel|url=http://kickerdaily.com/abs-cbn-partnership-with-viva-regal-to-air-classic-films-on-free-tv/|title=ABS-CBN forges partnership with Viva, Regal to air classic films on free TV|publisher=Kicker Daily News|date=March 16, 2016}}</ref> * March 20 – The [[PiliPinas Debates 2016 – Visayas leg|second leg]] of the [[PiliPinas Debates 2016]], a COMELEC-organized presidential debate held at the Performing Arts Hall of the [[University of the Philippines Cebu|University of the Philippines]], [[Cebu City]] and aired on [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]].
===April=== * April 10 – The [[PiliPinas Debates 2016 – Metro Manila leg|Metro Manila leg]] of the [[PiliPinas Debates 2016]], a COMELEC-organized first vice presidential debate held at the [[University of Santo Tomas]], [[Manila]] and aired on [[CNN Philippines]]. * April 17 ** [[Maxine Medina]], a graduate of the Philippine School of Interior Design with experience in designing residential condominiums and a model, is crowned as Miss Universe Philippines 2016 during the coronation night of the [[Binibining Pilipinas 2016]] at the [[Smart Araneta Coliseum]] in [[Quezon City]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rappler.com/life-and-style/specials/bb-pilipinas/129732-maxine-medina-crowned-miss-universe-philippines-2016-binibining-pilipinas | title=Maxine Medina crowned Miss Universe Philippines 2016 | publisher=''[[Rappler]]'' | date=April 18, 2016 | accessdate=April 18, 2016}}</ref> ** The [[Harapan ng Bise]]: The ABS-CBN Vice Presidential Debate, a televised debate created and organized by [[ABS-CBN]] held at the ABS-CBN Compound. * April 24 – The [[PiliPinas Debates 2016 – Luzon leg|third leg]] of the [[PiliPinas Debates 2016]], a COMELEC-organized presidential debate held at the [[University of Pangasinan]], [[Dagupan]] and aired on [[ABS-CBN]].
===May=== * May 1 – The [[ABS-CBN News Channel]] celebrated its 20th anniversary. * May 9–11 – All Philippine TV networks had its special coverage of the 2016 elections. * May 22 – Power Duo, composed of couple Anjanette and Gervin from [[Angono, Rizal]], wins the [[Pilipinas Got Talent (season 5)|fifth season]] of ''[[Pilipinas Got Talent]]'', the grand finals of which were held at the [[Mall of Asia Arena]] in [[Pasay]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/133904-power-duo-wins-pilipinas-got-talent-season-5-pgt5 | title=Power Duo wins 'Pilipinas Got Talent' season 5 | publisher=''[[Rappler]]'' | date=May 23, 2016 | accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref>
===June=== * June 30 – [[Jessy Mendiola]], a television actress, is hailed as ''The Nation's Sexiest Woman'' in FHM Philippines' 2016 100 Sexiest List.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/138147-jessy-mendiola-fhm-sexiest-woman-2016 | title=Jessy Mendiola is FHM's 'Sexiest Woman' 2016 | publisher=''[[Rappler]]'' | date=June 30, 2016 | accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref>
===July=== * July 11 – [[Alden Richards]] and [[Maine Mendoza]] were declared as ''The Most Beautiful Stars of 2016'' of ''YES!'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2016/07/13/1602135/yes-alden-maine-are-2016s-most-beautiful | title=Yes, Alden & Maine are 2016's ‘Most Beautiful’ | publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]'' | date=July 13, 2016 | accessdate=July 13, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/139335-aldub-cover-yes-most-beautiful-2016 | title=AlDub on the cover of YES! most beautiful 2016 | publisher=''[[Rappler]]'' | date=July 11, 2016 | accessdate=July 11, 2016}}</ref> * July 17 – The all-male group Tres Kantos, of Bugoy Drilon, [[Jovit Baldivino]], and former ''[[Tawag ng Tanghalan]]'' contestant Dominador Aviola, mentored by [[Erik Santos]], were named the first winner of the celebrity competition ''[[We Love OPM]]'' during the show's live finale at Resorts World Manila.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/07/17/16/tres-kantos-wins-we-love-opm | title=Tres Kantos wins 'We Love OPM' | publisher=''[[ABS CBN News]]'' | date=July 17, 2016 | accessdate=July 17, 2016}}</ref>
===August=== * August 21 – Alden Richards and Maine Mendoza, collectively known as AlDub, and [[Kathryn Bernardo]] and [[Daniel Padilla]], collectively known as KathNiel, and other Kapamilya and Kapuso personalities and programs were among the winners at the 2016 PEP List Awards night held at the Crown Plaza Hotel.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/08/21/16/kathniel-otwol-win-in-2016-pep-list-awards | title=KathNiel, 'OTWOL' win in 2016 PEP List Awards | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=August 21, 2016 | accessdate=August 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.interaksyon.com/entertainment/aldub-kathniel-dominate-3rd-pep-list-awards/ | title=AlDub, Kathniel dominate 3rd Pep List Awards | publisher=''InterAksyon'' | date=August 22, 2016 | accessdate=August 22, 2016 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160825090159/http://www.interaksyon.com/entertainment/aldub-kathniel-dominate-3rd-pep-list-awards/ | archivedate=August 25, 2016 | df= }}</ref> * August 28 – Joshua Oliveros, coached by [[Lea Salonga]], won the [[The Voice Kids (Philippines season 3)|third season]] of ''[[The Voice Kids (Philippine TV series)|The Voice Kids]]'', the grand finals of which were held at the [[Resorts World Manila|Newport Performing Arts Theatre, Resorts World Manila]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/08/28/16/antique-boy-named-voice-kids-season-3-champion | title=Antique boy named 'Voice Kids' season 3 champion | publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News]]'' | date=August 28, 2016 | accessdate=August 28, 2016}}</ref>
===September=== * September 26 – [[Jodi Sta. Maria]] and ''[[Bridges of Love]]'' were nominated for an [[International Emmy Award for Best Actress]] for her work in ''[[Pangako Sa 'Yo (2015 TV series)|Pangako Sa 'Yo]]'' and an [[International Emmy Award for best telenovela]] respectively at the 2016 [[International Emmy Awards]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Jodi Sta. Maria nominated for an Emmy|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/entertainment/2016/09/27/jodi-sta-maria-emmy-best-actress.html|date=September 27, 2016|publisher=[[CNN Philippines]]|author=Regine Cabato}}</ref>
===October=== * October 4 – During the 30th anniversary celebration held recently at the Marriott Grand Ballroom in [[Pasay]], [[DZMM-AM|DZMM]] announced the launch of the noontime national newscast ''[[Headline Pilipinas]],'' airing exclusively on [[DZMM TeleRadyo]] anchored by veteran broadcast journalist Tony Velasquez, together with [[DYCB-TV|ABS-CBN Cebu]]’s [[Leo Lastimosa]] and [[DXAS-TV|ABS-CBN Davao]]’s Melanie Severino.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.philstar.com/cebu-entertainment/2016/10/22/1636067/dzmm-launches-headline-pilipinas | title=DZMM launches ‘Headline Pilipinas’ | publisher=''Philstar'' | date=October 22, 2016 | accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref>
===November=== * November 15 – Following the success of the Fight of the Century between [[Manny Pacquiao]] and [[Floyd Mayweather Jr.]] in May 2015, [[Solar Entertainment Corporation|Solar Entertainment]] announced its broadcast of the [[Miss Universe 2016|65th Miss Universe]] pageant on January 30, 2017. As stated in a press conference that day, it was broadcast live on three major television stations in the Philippines, [[ABS-CBN (television network)|ABS-CBN]] (who waived its contract with Solar to allow its free-to-air coverage of the pageant), [[GMA Network]], and [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]] (who also broadcast the preliminary events and will handle the digital rights exclusively), with [[ETC (Philippine TV network)|ETC]], [[2nd Avenue (television channel)|2nd Avenue]], [[Jack TV]] and [[CT (TV channel)|CT]] as its main content provider for this historic pageant. [[Star World Philippines]], the Philippine cable broadcast holder of the pageant (which sub-licensed the cable rights to the pageant with the over-the-air rights holder ABS-CBN), will pass on the rights on that year's pageant to Solar, [[Miss Universe 2017|the 66th edition]] of the pageant will eventually returned to the channel in November 2017, 1 month after its rebranding to [[Fox Life]] in October.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/244101/miss-universe-pageant-will-push-through-in-ph-in-january-2017/|title=Miss Universe pageant will push through in PH in January, 2017|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|last=Adina|first=Arman P.|date=November 16, 2016|accessdate=November 17, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2016/12/19/1654852/tv5-beefs-2017-line|title=TV5 beefs up 2017 line-up|publisher=[[The Philippine Star]]|last=Lo|first=Ricky|date=December 19, 2016|accessdate=December 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/entertainment/gma/articles/2016-12-15/27516/GMA-Network-secures-a-partnership-with-Solar-Entertainment-for-Miss-Universe-2017-coverage|title=GMA Network secures a partnership with Solar Entertainment for Miss Universe 2017 coverage|publisher=[[GMA Network]]|last=Rodriguez|first=Bea|date=December 15, 2016|accessdate=December 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/life/12/22/16/abs-cbn-signs-deal-to-air-65th-miss-universe|title=ABS-CBN signs deal to air 65th Miss Universe|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News]]|date=December 22, 2016|accessdate=December 22, 2016}}</ref> * November 21 – ''[[The World Tonight (Philippine newscast)|The World Tonight]]'' celebrated its 50th anniversary of the longest-running English news program in the Philippines since its premiered in 1966.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/video/life/12/08/16/anc-marks-50-years-of-the-world-tonight |title=ANC marks 50 years of 'The World Tonight' |date=December 9, 2016 |publisher=ABS-CBN News}}</ref>
===December=== * December 11 – Niel Murillo, Russell Reyes, Ford Valencia, Tristan Ramirez and Joao Constancia were named as the winners of ''[[Pinoy Boyband Superstar]]'', and they will officially be called BoybandPH.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/12/11/16/meet-the-members-of-boybandph | title=Meet the members of BoybandPH | publisher=''[[ABS CBN News]]'' | date=December 11, 2016 | accessdate=December 11, 2016}}</ref> * December 15 – The team of [[Parul Shah]] and [[Maggie Wilson]], representing the Philippines, were held as winners at ''[[The Amazing Race Asia 5]]''. The team of [[Eric Tai|Eric]] and Rona Tai, also representing the Philippines, came in third place.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/155651-maggie-wilson-parul-shah-win-the-amazing-race-asia-5 | title=Maggie Wilson, Parul Shah win 'The Amazing Race Asia' season 5 | publisher=[[Rappler]] | date=December 15, 2016 | accessdate=December 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Debuts==
