revision.comment: /* top */ infobox
revision.text:
{{Infobox comic book title |title= Big Sleeping |image= Big Sleeping Il-mago-1977-cop.jpg |imagesize= 210 |caption= A cover of ''[[Il Mago (magazine)|Il Mago]]'' featuring ''Big Sleeping'' |format= |Genre= |Crime = y |Humor = y |publisher= |date= |issues= |main_char_team= |past_current_color= |writers= |artists= |creators= [[Daniele Panebarco]] }}'''Big Sleeping''' is an Italian noir-humorous comic series created by [[Daniele Panebarco]].
== History and profile == Inspired by [[Raymond Chandler]]'s novels, the main character of the series is a private detective loosely based on [[Philip Marlowe]]. The series featured typical noir and [[hard-boiled]] elements mixed with surreal and humorous plots, such as the research of [[Godot (character)|Godot]], or the thief of the [[Star of Bethlehem|Christmas Star]].<ref name=Fossati>{{cite book|last1=Franco Fossati|title=Dizionario Illustrato del Fumetto|publisher=Mondadori, 1992|isbn=8804355441|chapter=Big Sleeping}}</ref><ref name=xsz>Gianni Bono. "Big Sleeping". ''Guida al fumetto italiano''. Epierre, 2003.</ref>
The series debuted in the magazine ''[[Il Mago (magazine)|Il Mago]]'', and was later published in a large number of other publications including ''[[Linus (magazine)|linus]]'', ''[[Orient Express (magazine)|Orient Express]]'', ''Comic Art'' and ''[[L'espresso]]''. Big Sleeping was also featured in several graphic novels, the first of them being ''Il Falcone Sardese'' ([[Longanesi]], 1977), which featured the killing of [[Italian Communist Party]] secretary [[Enrico Berlinguer]] and his replacement with a double appointed to kill the American president [[Jimmy Carter]] during a public event.<ref name=Fossati>{{cite book|last1=Franco Fossati|title=Dizionario Illustrato del Fumetto|publisher=Mondadori, 1992|isbn=8804355441|chapter=Big Sleeping}}</ref><ref name=xsz>Gianni Bono. "Big Sleeping". ''Guida al fumetto italiano''. Epierre, 2003.</ref>
The appearance of the main character and the graphic rendering of the comics significantly evolved over the course of publications, from an early roundish and [[Fernando Botero|"boterian"]] style to a more stretched and realistic drawing.<ref name=Fossati>{{cite book|last1=Franco Fossati|title=Dizionario Illustrato del Fumetto|publisher=Mondadori, 1992|isbn=8804355441|chapter=Big Sleeping}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Pietro Favari|title=Le nuvole parlanti: un secolo di fumetti tra arte e mass media|isbn=8822004132|publisher=Dedalo, 2006|page=155}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |collapsible = |state = |title = Cultures: Discovery of Vinland |image = |caption = |developer = Funatics Software |publisher = Phenomedia |series = |engine = |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Mac OS]] |released = {{vgrelease|DE|September 1, 2000<ref name=pcgamesprev />|NA|July 31, 2001<ref name=gamespotrev />}} |genre = [[City-building game]] |modes = |director = |producer = |designer = |programmer = |artist = |writer = |composer = |alt = }}
'''''Cultures: Discovery of Vinland''''' ({{lang-de|Cultures: Die Entdeckung Vinlands}}) is a 2000 [[Real-time strategy game|real-time strategy]] and [[city-building game]] developed by Funatics Software and published by Phenomedia. It is the first entry in the ''Cultures'' series.
==Gameplay== ''Cultures'' is a [[Real-time strategy game|real-time strategy]] and [[city-building game]] in which players manage the historical [[Vinland]] settlements of the [[Viking]]s. This includes constructing roads, handling the settlement's economy and training citizens in jobs such as blacksmithing. The ultimate goal is to gather shards of a crashed meteor that possesses magical properties.<ref name=gamespotprev>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041123044932/http://www.gamespot.com:80/pc/strategy/cultures/news_2784741.html | url=http://www.gamespot.com:80/pc/strategy/cultures/news_2784741.html | title=First Look: ''Cultures'' | author=Beers, Craig | date=July 12, 2001 | work=[[GameSpot]] | archivedate=November 23, 2004 | deadurl=yes }}</ref>
==Development== ''Cultures'' was developed by Funatics Software, and was originally released in Europe during late 2000. Its North American release occurred on July 31, 2001.<ref name=gamespotrev />
==Reception== ===Sales=== As a city-building title, ''Cultures'' is part of a genre that tended to see success in European countries but "never seems to catch on in the States", [[GameSpot]]'s Bruce Geryk wrote in 2001.<ref name=gamespotrev /> ''[[PC Games (magazine)|PC Games]]'' billed it as a competitor to games such as ''[[The Settlers IV]]'' and ''[[Anno 1503]]''.<ref name=pcgamesprev>{{cite web | archiveurl=http://archive.is/HClgt |url=http://www.pcgames.de/Cultures-Die-Entdeckung-Vinlands-Spiel-20653/News/Wo-die-wilden-Wikinger-wuseln-4890/ | title=Wo die Wilden Wikinger wuseln | date=March 7, 2001 | author=Fröhlich, Petra | work=[[PC Games (magazine)|PC Games]] | archivedate=December 2, 2018 | language=[[German language|German]] | deadurl=no }}</ref> Retailers pre-purchased 140,000 units of ''Cultures'' in preparation for its release, and sales expectations were high; Funatics' previous title, ''Catan: Die Erste Insel'', had become a [[sleeper hit]].<ref name=140k>{{cite web| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20181203000355/https://www.gamestar.de/artikel/catan-erfolgreich,1334687.html |url=https://www.gamestar.de/artikel/catan-erfolgreich,1334687.html | title=''Catan'' erfolgreich'' | author=''GameStar'' Editors | date=September 11, 2000 | work=[[GameStar]] | language=[[German language|German]] | archivedate=December 3, 2018 | deadurl=no }}</ref> In the German market, ''Cultures'' debuted at #3 on Media Control's computer game sales chart for September 2000.<ref name=month1>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001024100349/http://www.vud.de:80/charts/pcg55.php3 | url=http://www.vud.de:80/charts/pcg55.php3 | title=Stand: September 2000 | publisher=Verband der Unterhaltungssoftware Deutschland | archivedate=October 24, 2000 | language=[[German language|German]] | deadurl=yes }}</ref> It placed sixth the following month, before falling to 16th in November.<ref name=month2>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001209002800/http://www.vud.de:80/charts/pcg55.php3 | url=http://www.vud.de:80/charts/pcg55.php3 | title=Stand: November 2000 | publisher=Verband der Unterhaltungssoftware Deutschland | archivedate=December 9, 2000 | language=[[German language|German]] | deadurl=yes }}</ref> Global sales of the game rose to 150,000 units by March 2002.<ref name=heise>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20181202190225/https://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Moorhuhnjaeger-schiessen-Vogel-beim-Umsatz-ab-64158.html| url=https://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Moorhuhnjaeger-schiessen-Vogel-beim-Umsatz-ab-64158.html | title=''Moorhuhnjäger'' schießen Vogel beim Umsatz ab | author=Ziegler, Peter-Michael | date=March 22, 2002 | work=[[Heinz Heise]] | archivedate=December 2, 2018 | language=[[German language|German]] | deadurl=no }}</ref>
===Critical reviews=== {{Video game reviews | GSpot = 5.8/10<ref name=gamespotrev>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041230134545/http://www.gamespot.com:80/pc/strategy/cultures/review.html | url=http://www.gamespot.com:80/pc/strategy/cultures/review.html | title=''Cultures'' | date=August 9, 2001 | author=Geryk, Bruce | work=[[GameSpot]] | archivedate=December 30, 2004 | deadurl=yes }}</ref> }}
{{-}}
==Legacy== ''Cultures'' was followed by three sequels: ''Cultures 2'', ''Cultures: Northland'' and ''Cultures: 8th Wonder of the World''.
The ''Cultures'' franchise became Funatics' most successful line, with combined sales above 700,000 units by 2018.<ref name=700k>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20181203002236/https://www.funatics.de/index.php/corporate.html | url=https://www.funatics.de/index.php/corporate.html | title=Funatics; Corporate | archivedate=December 3, 2018 | publisher=Funatics Software | language=[[German language|German]] | deadurl=no }}</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:2000 video games]] [[Category:Mac OS games]] [[Category:City-building games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Germany]]

{{infobox Organization |name = Federacion de Radioaficionados de Cuba
Cuban Amateur Radio Federation |image = Logotipo de los radioaficionados de Cuba.png |image_border = |size = 100px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = FRC |motto = |formation = |extinction = |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = |purpose = Advocacy, Education |headquarters = [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] |location = |region_served = [[Cuba]] |membership = 3,000 |language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Pedro Rodriguez CO2RP |main_organ = |affiliations = [[International Amateur Radio Union]] |num_staff = |budget = |website = https://www.frcuba.cu/ |remarks = }} The '''Federacion de Radioaficionados de Cuba''' ('''FRC''') (n [[English language|English]], '''Cuban Amateur Radio Federation''') is a national [[non-profit organization]] for [[amateur radio]] enthusiasts in [[Cuba]]. The FRC claims that 98% of all Cuban [[amateur radio operator]]s belong to the organization. These members are organized in 180 local amateur radio clubs that are affiliated with the Federacion de Radioaficionados de Cuba.Federacion de Radioaficionados de Cuba (2008). [http://frc.co.cu/frc3.htm "Federacion de Radioaficionados de Cuba"]. Retrieved Sep. 12, 2008. Key membership benefits of FRC include a [[QSL card|QSL]] bureau for those amateur radio operators in regular communications with other amateur radio operators in foreign countries and sponsorship of [[amateur radio operating award]]s and radio [[contesting|contests]]. FRC acts as a liaison between Cuban amateur radio operators and Cuban regulatory authorities. FRC is the national member society representing Cuba in the [[International Amateur Radio Union]].International Amateur Radio Union (2008). [http://www.iaru.org/iaru-soc.html "Member Societies"]. Retrieved Feb. 21, 2008. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:International Amateur Radio Union member societies|Cuba]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in Cuba]] [[Category:Radio in Cuba]] [[Category:Organizations based in Havana]] {{Cuba-stub}} {{Amateur-radio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4 | image = FNAF4Artwork.png | caption = [[Steam (software)|Steam]] storefront header | developer = [[Scott Cawthon]] | publisher = Scott Cawthon | series = ''[[Five Nights at Freddy's]]'' | engine = [[Clickteam Fusion 2.5]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] | released = '''Microsoft Windows'''{{Video game release|WW|{{start date|2015|7|23}}}}'''Android'''{{Video game release|WW|{{start date|2015|7|25}}}}'''iOS'''{{Video game release|WW|{{start date|2015|8|3}}}} | genre = [[Survival horror]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }}
'''''Five Nights at Freddy's 4''','' (often abbreviated to '''''FNaF4'''''), is an [[Indie game|indie]] [[Graphic adventure game|point-and-click]] [[survival horror]] [[video game]] created by [[Scott Cawthon]]. It is the fourth installment of the ''[[Five Nights at Freddy's]]'' series. Originally planned for release on October 31, 2015, the game was pushed forward to August 8, then again to July 23, when it was unexpectedly released on [[Steam (software)|Steam]].<ref name=FNAF4IGN>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/07/23/five-nights-at-freddys-4-jump-scares-a-surprise-early-release|title=Five Nights at Freddy's 4 Jump-Scares a Surprise Early Release|accessdate= July 23, 2015}}</ref> It was released for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices on July 25, 2015, and for [[iOS]] devices on August 3, 2015.
Announced in mid-2015 under the working title ''The Final Chapter'', the game is considered a departure from the previous games, which took place in a security office. Instead, the game takes place in a child's bedroom, placing an emphasis on timing and auditory warnings to complete nights.
Upon release, the game received polarizing reviews from critics; praise centered on its unsettling atmosphere, while others were divided over the game's new mechanics.
== Gameplay == <!-- Please do not add speculative content to this section or the plot section from YouTube videos, the FNAF Wiki, or your imagination as they are not considered reliable sources. --> {{refimprove section|date=September 2015}} Unlike previous ''Five Nights at Freddy's'' games, the game is not set in a security office, but in a child's bedroom. There are no cameras, and instead of "Phone Guy", the player is given on-screen instructions to help the player during the game.<ref name="KotakuAll">{{cite web | url=http://kotaku.com/everything-we-know-about-five-nights-at-freddys-4-so-f-1720003919 | title=Everything We Know About Five Nights at Freddy's 4 (So Far) | publisher=Kotaku | date=July 24, 2015 | accessdate=July 25, 2015 | author=Hernandez, Patricia}}</ref> The player is equipped with a flashlight, similar to the [[Five Nights at Freddy's 2|second game]], although the light has unlimited power.<ref name= "Destruct">{{cite web | url=http://www.destructoid.com/review-five-nights-at-freddy-s-4-296612.phtml | title=Review: Five Nights at Freddy's 4 | publisher=[[Destructoid]] | date=July 24, 2015 | accessdate=July 25, 2015 | author=Rowen, Nic}}</ref> It can be used to ward away any animatronics seen down the hall; however, if the player hears either Nightmare Bonnie's or Nightmare Chica's breathing at the door or they see Nightmare Fredbear or Nightmare upon turning on the flashlight, they must immediately close the door, however, the door will open as the player walks away. The player must also monitor the closet to avoid getting attacked by Nightmare Foxy by closing it if necessary, as well as shooing three miniature animatronics named 'Freddles' on the bed before they summon Nightmare Freddy to attack the player. If the player is not careful in shining the light towards the hallways or leaves the doors, closet, and bed unattended for too long, the player will be [[jump scare|jumpscared]], leading to a [[game over]].
After beating each night, the player can play a timed minigame titled "Fun with Plushtrap", where they must try to stop a small [[stuffed toy|plush toy]] version of Springtrap, the central animatronic in ''[[Five Nights at Freddy's 3]]'', on top of an "X" marked on the ground within a specific amount of time. If the player wins, the player will start the next night at 2 AM. Like the nightmare animatronics, this timed minigame becomes more difficult as the game progresses. It is impossible to use the time bonus in the unlockable modes. Additionally, if the player gets a game over, the bonus is no longer valid for further plays of the same level.
Like previous games, the game's main storyline takes place over five increasingly-difficult nights with unlockable extra levels. The first four nights will put the player against four animatronics: Nightmare Freddy, Nightmare Bonnie, Nightmare Chica, and Nightmare Foxy. Nightmare Fredbear, who combines the scare tactics of the previous four, is the sole attacker on the fifth night. Completing all five nights will unlock an additional sixth night, where the four animatronics will haunt the player until Nightmare Fredbear takes over when the clock hits 4 AM. Completing the sixth night will unlock the "Nightmare" night, where the animatronics are very persistent and Nightmare Fredbear is replaced by the highly aggressive Nightmare, who has a unique game over screen compared to other animatronics. A secret code will unlock an eighth night based on the Custom Night modes from the first two games, which sets the [[Artificial intelligence|A.I.]] of the animatronics to maximum difficulty. Other unlockables include galleries of the various animatronics and jumpscares, as well as behind-the-scenes looks at the 3D-modelling process for Fredbear and Foxy.<ref name="Extras">{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon| publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene =Extras menu| quote = }}</ref>
As in most of the previous entries of the series, the story of the game is revealed in interactive [[Retrogaming|Atari-style]] minigame sections between nights. Each of the minigames are set in a time frame corresponding to the five nights, beginning with "5 days until the party", up to "0 days until the party".
== Plot ==
The game starts with a minigame which shows a young boy who is locked in his bedroom with plush toys, which he calls his friends.<ref>{{cite video game|title=Five Nights at Freddy's 4|developer=Scott Cawthon|publisher=|platform=[[Personal computer|PC]]|scene=Night 1 prologue|date=July 23, 2015|quote='''Boy:''' These are my friends.}}</ref> It is speculated that ''Five Nights at Freddy's 4''<nowiki/>'s gameplay is the result of the boy suffering from nightmares that he is being attacked by the animatronics, and must protect himself. After the player survives the first night, Fredbear tells the boy that "he" (Michael Afton the boy's brother) is hiding in the house, before the boy is jumpscared by Michael Afton his brother, who is wearing a Foxy mask.<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 2 prologue| quote = '''Fredbear:''' Now he is hiding again. He won't stop until you find him.}}</ref> After the second night, the boy is abandoned at the pizzeria, only to be warned by Fredbear's voice that "he" is coming and that he needs to be brave; however, the boy is afraid of the animatronics and costumed mascots, and ends up crying. An [[Easter egg (interaction design)|easter egg]] during this scene briefly shows the "William Afton" from the [[Five Nights at Freddy's 2|second]] and [[Five Nights at Freddy's 3|third]] games placing someone in the Spring Bonnie suit.<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 3 prologue| quote = '''Fredbear:''' You're too late. Hurry the other way and find someone who will help! You know what will happen if he catches you! You can find help if you can get past them. You need to be strong.}}</ref>
After the third night, the minigame reveals that other children tease the boy, calling him a coward and crybaby,<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 4 prologue| quote = '''Boy 1:''' Aren't you the kid who always hides under the table and cries? Hahaha! No one else is scared! Why are you? Stop being such a baby!}}</ref> and that there are rumors of the animatronics coming to life at night and attempting to murder people.<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 4 prologue| quote = '''Girl 2:''' You'd better watch out! I hear they come to life at night. And if you die, they hide your body and never tell anyone.}}</ref> The boy sees his plush toys as his only friends and generally eschews interaction with other people in favor of them. After the fourth night, it is revealed that he was once locked in the building's parts and services room as a prank.<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 5 prologue| quote = '''You:''' Please let me out. PLEASE! Please let me out...}}</ref> If the fifth night is completed, the boy is shown crying at his own birthday party in the pizzeria. “Michael Afton” turns out to be the boy's brother, alongside other bullies wearing the masks of the animatronics to terrorize the boy.<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 5 epilogue| quote = '''Your Brother's Friend:''' Wow, your brother is kind of a baby, isn't he? / '''Michael Afton:''' It's hilarious.}}</ref> The bullies, deciding to prank the boy, grab him and try to get him close to the mouth of Fredbear for a "kiss"<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 5 epilogue| quote = '''Michael Afton:''' Why don't we help him get a closer look! He will love it. / '''You:''' Please! / ''Michael Afton:''' Come on, guys, let's give this little man a lift. He wants to get up close and personal! / '''You:''' No! I don't want to go! / '''Michael Afton:''' You heard the little man! He wants to get even closer! Ha ha ha!}}</ref> and end up stuffing the boy's head into the mouth of Fredbear.<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 5 epilogue| quote = '''Michael Afton:''' Hey guys, I think the little man said he wants to give the Fredbear a big kiss! On THREE! One...two...}}</ref> Suddenly, Fredbear, who was in the middle of singing, forcefully closes his mouth, resulting in the boy's head being crushed while Michael Afton and his friends stare in horror.
After the sixth night, the boy hears a voice apologizing to him,<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 6 epilogue| quote = '''Voice:''' Can you hear me? I don't know if you can hear me. I'm sorry.}}</ref> as Fredbear promises him that no matter how many times he "breaks", he and the others will always be there to "put him back together" and will always be his friends.<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Night 6 epilogue| quote = '''Fredbear:''' You're broken. We're still your friends. Do you still believe that? I'm still here. I will put you back together.}}</ref> The characters then fade out one by one, and the faint sound of a [[electrocardiography|heart monitor]] flatlining can be heard, ending the game. Following this, the player unlocks Nightmare mode, which is the same as the sixth night with the exception of a new animatronic, Nightmare, a more aggressive version of Nightmare Fredbear.
If the player completes Nightmare mode, an image of a locked metal trunk is displayed; if the player wiggles the padlocks, the game eventually states "Perhaps some things are best left forgotten, for now."<ref>{{cite video game| title = Five Nights at Freddy's 4| developer = Scott Cawthon | publisher = | date = July 23, 2015| platform = [[Personal computer|PC]]| scene = Nightmare epilogue}}</ref> Cawthon has remained cryptic about what is inside the trunk, and eventually announced that he will not disclose what is in it. He gave only one clue: "What's in the box? It's the pieces [of the franchise's story] put together."
== Development and release == Beginning April 27, 2015, Cawthon posted images on his website teasing at another game in the series, originally known as ''Five Nights at Freddy's: The Final Chapter''. The images, featuring the characters from the hies, cryptically teased at a release on Halloween.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.vg247.com/2015/04/28/five-nights-at-freddys-4-release-date/ | title = Five Night’s at Freddy’s 4 teased for Halloween release | first =Brenna | last = Hillier | date = April 28, 2015 | accessdate = May 16, 2015 | work = [[VG247]]|publisher = Videogaming 247 Ltd. }}</ref> A trailer was released on July 13, 2015, hinting that the game took place in the main character's house. The subtitle, ''The Final Chapter'', was dropped.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.polygon.com/2015/7/13/8955575/five-nights-at-freddys-4-trailer|title= Five Nights at Freddy's 4 trailer gets its first creepy trailer|author= Campbell, Colin|work= [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|publisher= [[Vox Media]]|date= July 13, 2015|accessdate= July 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.cnet.com/news/freddy-follows-you-home-in-trailer-for-five-nights-at-freddys-4/|title= Freddy follows you home in trailer for Five Nights at Freddy's 4|author= Gallagher, Danny|work= [[CNET]]|publisher= [[CBS Corporation]]|date= July 14, 2015|accessdate= July 28, 2015}}</ref>
A demo for the game was released to select YouTubers on July 21, 2015, with the full game being released on July 23, 2015.<ref name=FNAF4IGN/> The game was released for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices on July 25, 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gamezebo.com/2015/07/25/five-nights-at-freddys-4-is-now-on-android/|title= Five Nights at Freddy’s 4 Is Now on Android|author= Jim Squires|publisher= [[Gamezebo]]|date= July 25, 2015|accessdate= July 29, 2015}}</ref> and for [[iOS]] devices on August 3, 2015. On October 31, 2015, two updates for the game were released. One consists of a set of cheat options, challenge modes, and an altered version of the "Fun with Plushtrap" minigame that uses a nightmare version of the character Balloon Boy (from ''[[Five Nights at Freddy's 2]]'') in place of Plushtrap. The second is a "Halloween Edition" that makes cosmetic changes to Nightmare Bonnie and Nightmare Chica, and introduces nightmare versions of the second game's characters Mangle and The Puppet, the former replacing Nightmare Foxy and the latter replacing Nightmare. Nightmare Cupcake is also replaced with a jack-o-lantern.
==Reception== {{VG reception | MC = (PC) 51/100<ref name="MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/five-nights-at-freddys-4 |title=Five Nights at Freddy's 4 for PC Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Corporation]] |accessdate=August 13, 2015}}</ref> | Destruct = 4/10<ref name="Destruct"/> | PCGUS = 70/100<ref name="PCG">{{cite web|url= http://www.pcgamer.com/five-nights-at-freddys-4-review/|title= Five Nights at Freddy's 4 Review on PC Gamer|publisher= [[PC Gamer]]|date= August 5, 2015|accessdate= August 13, 2015}}</ref> | rev1 = ''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' | rev1Score = {{rating|4|5}}<ref name="The Escapist"/> | rev2 = ''[[Gamezebo]]'' | rev2Score = {{rating|4|5}}<ref name="GZ"/> | rev3 = ''[[TouchArcade]]'' | rev3Score = (iOS) {{rating|3|5}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://toucharcade.com/2015/08/10/five-nights-at-freddys-4-review/ |title='Five Nights At Freddy's 4' Review – The Latest Freddy Gets The Worst Port Yet |last=Musgrave |first=Shaun |date=August 10, 2015 |website=[[TouchArcade]] |accessdate=July 17, 2018}}</ref> }}
The PC version of the game received an aggregate score of 51 out of 100 on [[Metacritic]] based on 6 reviews.<ref name= "MC"/>
''[[Destructoid]]'' criticized the gameplay as being too confusing, and gave the game a review score of 4 out of 10.<ref name= "Destruct"/> ''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' gave the game a positive review score of 4 out of 5 stars saying that they liked the reworked mechanics, darker and emotional storyline, scary jumpscares, and sad ending but noted the game's bugs and glitches.<ref name= "The Escapist">{{cite web|url= http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video-games/editorials/reviews/14363-Five-Nights-at-Freddy-s-4-Review-Worth-Playing|title= Five Nights at Freddy's 4 Review - Change, Improve, Jumpscare|author= Angelo M. D'Argeno|work= [[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]|publisher= [[Defy Media]]|date= July 28, 2015|accessdate= July 29, 2015}}</ref> Nadia Oxford of [[Gamezebo]] gave it 4 out of 5 stars in her review praising it for its intense environment, creepy sounds and graphics, and jumpscares. She criticised the game for being difficult to survive in certain environments when relying on audio cues and the Android version not containing the story-centric minigames.<ref name= "GZ">{{cite web|url= http://www.gamezebo.com/2015/07/30/five-nights-at-freddys-4-review-hey-listen/|title= Five Nights at Freddy’s 4 Review: Hey! Listen!|author= Nadia Oxford|publisher= [[GameZebo]]|date= July 30, 2015|accessdate= August 1, 2015}}</ref>

page.title: Gamer Symphony Orchestra at the University of Maryland

revision.comment: send to series
revision.text:
{{Infobox orchestra | name = Gamer Symphony Orchestra at the University of Maryland | type = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | short_name = GSO | image =File: GSO Logo.png | caption = | alt = | former_name = | founded = {{Start date|2005}} | disbanded = <!-- {{End date|YYYY}} --> | later_name = | location = [[University of Maryland]], [[College Park, Maryland]] | concert_hall = Dekelboum Concert Hall at the [[Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center]] | principal_conductor = | music_director = | website = {{URL|http://umd.gamersymphony.org/}} }} The '''Gamer Symphony Orchestra at the University of Maryland''' (often referred to as the '''GSO''', '''UMGSO''', or '''UMDGSO''') is a student-run [[symphony orchestra]] and [[choir|chorus]] at the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]]. The orchestra is the first collegiate ensemble to draw its repertoire exclusively from the music of video games.<ref name="sentinel">{{Cite news | last = Stein | first = Ron | title = Video game music finds new outlet in UM symphony | work = The Sentinel | accessdate = 2010-08-05 | date = 2009-12-09 | url = http://www.thesentinel.com/pgs/Video-game-symphony }}</ref><ref name="diamondback">{{Cite news | last = Floyd | first = Thomas | title = Beating on Donkey Kong's drum | work = The Diamondback | accessdate = 2010-07-29 | date = 2008-05-12 | url = http://www.diamondbackonline.com/2.2793/beating-on-donkey-kong-s-drum-1.281168 }}</ref><ref name="examiner">{{Cite news | last = Gullard | first = Marie | title = Symphonic 'bleeps' fill the hall at University of Maryland | work = The Washington Examiner | accessdate = 2011-12-13 | date = 2011-11-30 | url = http://washingtonexaminer.com/entertainment/music/2011/11/symphonic-bleeps-fill-hall-university-maryland/1965661 }}</ref><ref name="bsun">{{Cite news | last = Kaltenbach | first = Chris | title = Super Mario Bros. in D-minor | work = The Baltimore Sun | accessdate = 2013-04-27 | date = 2013-04-27 | url = http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/arts/bs-ae-gamer-symphony-20130427,0,6735486,full.story }} </ref> Most of GSO's members are non-music majors<ref name="bsun" /><ref name="Post">{{Cite news | issn = 0740-5421 | last = Midgette | first = Anne | title = Video-game concerts, a movement that's more than a blip on orchestral landscape | work = The Washington Post | accessdate = 2010-07-28 | date = 2010-07-28 | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/07/27/AR2010072705500.html?hpid=newswell }}</ref><ref name="gazette1">{{Cite news | title = Gamer Symphony Orchestra performs spring concert | work = The Gazette | accessdate = 2010-08-05 | date = 2009-04-23 | url = http://www.gazette.net/stories/04232009/greenew182108_32524.shtml }}</ref> The orchestra holds a free concert every semester during the [[academic year]] and yearly charity fundraisers that benefit the [[Children's National Medical Center]] in Washington, D.C.<ref name="gazette" /><ref name="goodgaming">{{Cite news | last = Kirkwood | first = Lauren | title = Gamer Symphony Orchestra performs spring concert | work = The Diamondback | accessdate = 2011-05-18 | date = 2011-03-13 | url = http://www.diamondbackonline.com/news/gaming-for-good-1.2106178 }}</ref>
==History== Michelle Eng, a violist in the [[University of Maryland School of Music|School of Music]]'s Repertoire Orchestra, founded GSO in the fall of 2005.<ref name="gazette3">{{Cite news | last = Schuman | first = Jonah | title = UM orchestra specializes in video game music | work = The Gazette | accessdate = 2010-08-05 | date = 2008-11-27 | url = http://www.gazette.net/stories/11272008/prinnew185652_32500.shtml }}</ref> The group's first public performance was April 29, 2006, and featured about 20 musicians. The GSO added a choir in the fall of 2007,<ref name="gazette3"/> by which time the ensemble totaled 50 musicians.<ref name="tribune">{{Cite web | last = Hollenbeck | first = Stacey | title = College orchestra plays thumb-wiggling video-game music | date = 2007-10-30 | url = http://www.allbusiness.com/education-training/students-student-life/14757604-1.html | accessdate = 2011-01-28}}</ref> As of spring 2010 the orchestra had 100 members, including 30 [[choir|choral singers]].<ref name="gazette">{{Cite news | last = Hill | first = David | title = Super Mario meets Mozart | work = The Gazette | accessdate = 2010-07-28 | date = 2010-05-06 | url = http://www.gazette.net/stories/05062010/entepri140109_32547.php }}</ref> By fall of 2010, its numbers had surpassed 100,<ref name="terp">{{Cite news |last = M |first = K |title = A Score for the Gamers |work = TERP Magazine |accessdate = 2010-11-04 |url = http://www.terp.umd.edu/4.6/spotlight/ |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110308012231/http://www.terp.umd.edu/4.6/spotlight/ |archivedate = 2011-03-08 |df = }}</ref><ref name="mpr">{{Cite news | last = Reese | first = Emily | title = Getting to know the Gamer Symphony Orchestra | work = Classical Minnesota Public Radio | accessdate = 2011-01-18 | date = 2011-01-13 | url = http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/01/13/gamer-symphony-orchestra/ }}</ref> and as of spring 2013, membership is at 120. The orchestra continues to boast large membership consisting of 100+ members every semester.<ref name="bsun" />
The development of this orchestra mirrors the acceptance of classical music concerts [[Video game music#Video game music outside video games|anchored by video game music]] in the [[United States]]. Eng founded this group after having been inspired by [[Video Games Live]], the [[Final Fantasy concerts|Dear Friends]] concert series, and "[[Video Game Pianist]]" Martin Leung.<ref name="bsun" /><ref name="malik">{{Cite news | last = Malik | first = Alia | title = Still 'playing' Nintendo | newspaper = The Diamondback | accessdate = 2010-12-03 | url = http://www.diamondbackonline.com/2.2793/still-playing-nintendo-1.289761 | date = 2006-04-24 }} </ref>
Composer [[Jonathan Coulton]] complimented the GSO's 2008 performance of "[[Still Alive]]," from the popular video game "[[Portal (video game)|Portal]]," calling it a "fantastic cover" in a post on his blog.<ref name="coulton">{{cite web | last = Coulton | first = Jonathan | title = Gamer Symphony Orchestra | date = 2008-07-22 | url = http://www.jonathancoulton.com/2008/07/22/gamer-symphony-orchestra/ | accessdate = 2010-08-03}} </ref> This recording was posted to [[OverClocked ReMix|OC ReMix]] as only the second live recording in the history of the site—the first accepted ReMix of music from "Portal."<ref name="ocremix">{{cite web | title = ReMix: Portal 'Live from [SUBJECT HOMETOWN HERE]' | publisher = [[OC ReMix]] | date = 2009-05-05 | url = http://ocremix.org/remix/OCR01838/ | accessdate = 2010-08-03}} </ref> OC ReMix founder David Lloyd was present for GSO's first live performance of "Still Alive."<ref name="ocremix" />
The GSO's concert on Dec. 11, 2010, overfilled the capacity of the 1,170-seat Dekelboum Concert Hall,<ref name="mpr" /> the largest concert hall at the university's [[Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center]].
The [[Video Games Live]] concert on Feb. 26, 2011, at [[Strathmore (Maryland)|Strathmore]] in Bethesda, Md., featured "a special contribution" from the GSO.<ref name="strathmore">{{cite web | title = Strathmore Presents Video Games Live | date = 2011-02-04 | url = http://www.strathmore.org/press/pressreleases/view.asp?id=41255578 | accessdate = 2011-02-11}} </ref><ref name="edwards">{{Cite news | last = Edwards | first = Jordan | title = Not just for kids: Concert gives video games orchestral edge | work = The Gazette | accessdate = 2011-02-23 | date = 2011-02-23 | url = http://gazette.net/stories/02232011/entemon131512_32536.php }}</ref><ref name="nbc">{{Cite news | title = Symphony Plays Video Game Classics | work = NBC Washington | accessdate = 2011-02-27 | date = 2011-02-27 | url = http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Musicians-Combine-Classical-Music-and-Video-Games-117007288.html }}</ref> GSO and Video Games Live staff began discussing collaborative possibilities in August 2010 for the pair of Strathmore concerts.<ref name="patch">{{Cite news | last = Ouedraogo | first = Julie | title = The Music of Video Games Meets an Orchestra at Strathmore | work = RockvillePatch | accessdate = 2011-03-02 | date = 2011-03-01 | url = http://rockville.patch.com/articles/video-the-music-of-video-games-meets-an-orchestra-at-strathmore#video-5078294 }}</ref> VGL founder [[Tommy Tallarico]] chose to include an adapted version of GSO's arrangement of "[[Korobeiniki]]" ("A-Type") from ''[[Tetris]]'' in the Strathmore concert programs.<ref name="patch" /> The [[National Philharmonic at Strathmore|National Philharmonic Orchestra]] and Chorale performed the piece, arranged by GSO Conductor Emeritus Greg Cox. Former GSO Music Director and current singer Chris Apple performed the piece's tenor solo. The arrangement appeared on Video Games Live's third album which was released in February 2014.
The ensemble's spring 2011 concert featured Mark Cromer, the senior sound designer for [[Big Huge Games]], as a guest banjo player.<ref name="gameon">{{Cite news | last = Forhecz | first = Topher | title = Game on at University of Maryland | work = The Gazette | accessdate = 2011-05-18 | date = 2011-05-05 | url = http://www.gazette.net/stories/05052011/entepri121421_32534.php }}</ref> Cromer joined the GSO for a medley of "[[Banjo-Kazooie]]" themes, with an arrangement by tubist David Scherr.<ref name="gameon" /> [[Grant Kirkhope]], who composed the original music, attended the performance.<ref name="gameon" /> The spring concert, at which the GSO observed its fifth anniversary, also featured a performance of "[[Music of the Final Fantasy VII series|Electric de Chocobo]]" from "[[Final Fantasy VII]]" by the [[Magruder High School]] Gamer Symphony Orchestra.<ref name="gameon" /><ref name="mhspatch">{{Cite news | last = Mayer | first = Valerie | title = Magruder HS Gamer Symphony Orchestra (GSO) Joins with UMD GSO | work = RockvillePatch | accessdate = 2011-05-18 | url = http://rockville.patch.com/events/magruder-hs-gamer-symphony-orchestra-gso-joins-with-umd-gso }}</ref>
Video Games Live again performed GSO's Korobeiniki arrangement, under the title "Tetris Opera," at [[L.A. Live]]'s Nokia Theatre on June 8, 2011.<ref name="e3">{{cite web | title = Video Games Live Celebrates its 200th Show in Los Angeles During E3! | date = 2011-05-26 | url = http://videogameslive.com/index.php?story=276 | accessdate = 2011-06-09}} </ref> The show (VGL's 200th) was put on in partnership with the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo]].<ref name="e3" />
Spring 2012 marked the first semester in which the GSO performed outside of the University of Maryland. Firstly, at the Music and Gaming Festival (MAGFest) X, and secondly at the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]], as part of the [[The Art of Video Games|Art of Video Games]] exhibit.<ref name="cbs">{{cite news | last = Johnson | first = Whit | title = Video game orchestra strikes nostalgic chord | work = CBS This Morning | date = 2012-05-29 | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505270_162-57442656/video-game-orchestra-strikes-nostalgic-chord/ }}</ref>
The ensemble dedicated its spring 2013 concert to the memory of its tubist, David Scherr, who died in December 2012. Shortly after his passing, the orchestra purchased the tuba that Scherr had been renting and had his name engraved on it. The tuba is now loaned to members who are unable to provide their own instrument.<ref name="blasey">{{Cite news | last = Blasey | first = Laura | title = Gamer Symphony Orchestra holds memorial for former member, David Scherr, who died last month | newspaper = The Diamondback | accessdate = 2013-01-25 | url = http://www.diamondbackonline.com/news/campus/article_c734ade6-66ac-11e2-b9be-001a4bcf6878.html | date = 2013-01-25 }} </ref>
After the 2013 semester ended, Chris Apple, Ayla Hurley, Rob Garner, and other alums founded the Washington Metropolitan Gamer Symphony Orchestra in Rockville, MD as an outlet for GSO graduates and other community musicians to come together and perform video game music.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://umd.gamersymphony.org/history.php|title=The Gamer Symphony Orchestra at the University of Maryland|website=umd.gamersymphony.org|access-date=2018-04-02}}</ref>
In 2015, the GSO returned to the Smithsonian American Art Museum to perform as part of the “Watch This! Revelations in Media Art” exhibition.<ref name=":0" />
The Fall 2015 and Spring 2016 semesters marked the 10th year milestone for the GSO’s foundation and first public performance respectively. Alongside the celebrations, in Fall 2015, the GSO started livestreaming its concerts on Twitch.<ref name=":0" />
In March 2018, the orchestra performed at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]] on [[Millennium Stage]], as part of their Direct Current performances, and featured many emeritus members. The orchestra performed various pieces which included Apotheosis, from the game [[Journey (2012 video game)|Journey]], which was personally approved by the composer [[Austin Wintory]].
==Concertography==
Performance venues have included the University of Maryland's [[Hoff Theater]], [[Memorial Chapel (University of Maryland)|Memorial Chapel]] and [[Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center]], the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]], and the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]].
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Semester ! Games Performed (Selection) |- | 2014 Spring | ''[[Animal Crossing: New Leaf]]'', ''[[Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword]]'', ''[[Mass Effect]]'', ''[[Pokémon Red and Blue]]'' |- | 2013 Fall | ''[[Sam & Max Hit The Road]]'', ''[[Final Fantasy VI]]'', ''[[Uncharted 2]]'', ''[[Mega Man 2]]'' |- | 2013 Spring | ''[[Kid Icarus]]'', ''[[Donkey Kong 64]]'', ''[[Journey (2012 video game)|Journey]]'', ''[[Skyrim]]'' |- | 2012 Fall | ''[[MapleStory]]'', ''[[Final Fantasy VI]]'', ''[[World of Warcraft]]'', ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time]]'' |- | 2012 Spring | ''[[Dragon Quest]]'', ''[[Bastion (video game)|Bastion]]'', ''[[flOw]]'', ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (series)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]'', ''[[The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker]]'' |- | 2011 Fall | ''[[Pokémon]]'', ''[[Shadow of the Colossus]]'', ''[[Civilization V]]'', ''[[Disgaea: Hour of Darkness]]'', ''[[Kingdom Hearts II]]'' |- | 2011 Spring | ''[[Banjo-Kazooie]]'', ''[[Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney]]'', ''[[The Oregon Trail (series)|Oregon Trail]]'', ''[[Portal (video game)|Portal]]'', ''[[Secret of Mana]]'' |- | 2010 Fall | ''[[Xenosaga]]'', ''[[Touhou]]'', ''[[Mega Man (video game)|Mega Man]]'', ''[[Donkey Kong Country]]'', ''[[Final Fantasy VI]]'' |- | 2010 Spring | ''[[Super Mario Galaxy]]'',<ref group="n">Arrangement courtesy of the Boston-based [[Video Game Orchestra]].</ref> ''[[Final Fantasy XII]]'', ''[[The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker]]'', ''[[Civilization IV]]'' |- | 2009 Fall | ''[[Final Fantasy IX]]'', ''[[Final Fantasy X]]'', ''[[Tetris]]'' |- | 2009 Spring | ''[[Portal (video game)|Portal]]'', ''[[Kingdom Hearts]]'', ''[[Katamari Damacy]]'' |- | 2008 Fall | ''[[Final Fantasy VIII]]'', ''[[Warcraft II]]'', ''[[Star Fox (video game)|Star Fox]]'' |- | 2008 Spring | ''[[Final Fantasy XIII]]'', ''[[Super Mario 64]]'', ''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' |- | 2007 Fall | ''[[Halo (series)|Halo]]'', ''[[Star Fox 64]]'', ''[[Medal of Honor: Frontline]]'' |- | 2007 Spring | ''[[Donkey Kong Country 2: Diddy's Kong Quest]]'', ''[[Xenosaga]]'', ''[[Super Mario RPG]]'' |- | 2006 Fall | ''[[Super Mario Bros. 2]]'', ''[[Tetris]]'', ''[[Final Fantasy (video game)|Final Fantasy]]'' |- | 2006 Spring | ''[[The Legend of Zelda (1986 video game)|The Legend of Zelda]]'', ''[[Final Fantasy (video game)|Final Fantasy]]'', ''[[Kingdom Hearts]]'' |}
Full recordings of recent concerts can be downloaded from the group's [http://umd.gamersymphony.org/?page_id=16 website].
==Arrangements==
Group members produce the [[arrangements]] that this orchestra performs.<ref name="Post"/><ref name="gazette1"/><ref name="will_franklin">{{Cite news |last=Franklin |first=Will |title=Melodies from the console to be performed at University of Maryland |work=The Gazette |accessdate=2013-05-06 |date=2013-05-02 |url=http://www.gazette.net/article/20130502/ENTERTAINMENT/130509662/1032/melodies-from-the-console-to-be-performed-at-university-of-maryland&template=gazette |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130703055207/http://www.gazette.net/article/20130502/ENTERTAINMENT/130509662/1032/melodies-from-the-console-to-be-performed-at-university-of-maryland&template=gazette |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-07-03 }}</ref> Anyone is allowed to submit an arrangement, however each piece is run through a critique and voted on by the group’s music committee (consisting of the music director, the orchestra conductors, choral conductor, and the vice president) before it is accepted and put into the program for a given semester.<ref name="n00balert">{{Cite news | last = Smith | first = Matthew | title = The Gamer Symphony Orchestra at the University of MD | work = N00bAlert.com | accessdate = 2012-04-23 | date = 2012-03-26 | url = http://www.n00balert.com/the-gamer-symphony-orchestra-at-the-university-of-md-30740/ }}</ref>
== Legacy == The Maryland GSO hopes to inspire and assist in the creation of more GSOs in the future. They have openly encouraged high school and college students who are interested in starting a GSO at their school to contact them.
The GSO's fall 2008 concert inspired students at [[Colonel Zadok A. Magruder High School|Magruder High School]] in [[Rockville, Maryland|Rockville, Md.]], to found their own video game orchestra.<ref name="gazette1"/><ref name="gazette"/> The similarly named Magruder Gamer Symphony Orchestra performs regularly at the high school's instrumental music concerts as the only non-classroom ensemble.
In fall 2010, the Maryland GSO helped to establish a similar ensemble at [[Damascus High School]] in [[Damascus, Maryland|Damascus, Md.]]<ref name="diamondback2"> {{Cite news | last = Wildman | first = May | title = More than just regular gamers | work = The Diamondback | accessdate = 2010-12-17 | date = 2010-12-09 | url = http://www.diamondbackonline.com/diversions/more-than-just-regular-gamers-1.1828057 }} </ref>
Upon hearing about the Maryland GSO, a student at [[Ithaca College]] founded the Ithaca College GSO in 2011. The ensemble's premiere concert was Nov. 11, 2012.<ref name="ithacan"> {{Cite news | last = Eisenberg | first = Jackie | title = Play That Funky Music, Game Boy | work = The Ithacan | accessdate = 2012-09-27 | date = 2012-09-26 | url = http://theithacan.org/25250 }} </ref>
Tyler Modesto was inspired by the “Art of Video Games” exhibit at the Smithsonian and started the 8-bit Orchestra at the University of Delaware.
==See also== *[[Video game music]] *[[Video Games Live]] *[[Play! A Video Game Symphony]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} {{update|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox award | name = Golden Kela Awards | image = | imagesize = | caption = | description = Worst in Hindi Cinema | presenter = ''[[Random Magazine]]'' | country = India | year = 2009{{cite news| url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-02-22/news-interviews/37241143_1_anti-kelas-golden-kela-awards-anti-kela | work=The Times Of India | title=Golden Kela Awards organizers announce Anti-Kela Award winners - The Times of India}} | website = [http://www.goldenkela.com/ www.goldenkela.com] }} The '''Golden Kela Awards''' ({{lang-hi|गोल्डन केला अवॉर्ड्स}}) are a satirical take on [[Bollywood]] that award the worst performances in Hindi cinema each year.{{cite news | url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/india-s-razzies-golden-kela-awards-rigged/story-knQGKs7BA2fIfHEimpgnMI.html|title=India’s razzies Golden Kela Awards rigged?|date=31 January 2014|first=Debasmita|last=Ghosh|newspaper=Hindustan Times|accessdate=1 July 2018}} Created by ''[[Random Magazine]]'', winners are selected each year by an online poll and receive an award in the shape of a golden banana (केला ''kelā'' in [[Hindi]]).{{cite news|title= Golden Kela awards Winners|publisher=Times Of India|url=http://photogallery.indiatimes.com/celebs/celeb-themes/Golden-Kela-awards-Winners/articleshow/5684898.cms|accessdate=2010-03-15}} The first award ceremony took place on 7 March 2009 in [[New Delhi]] (India).[http://movies.ndtv.com/video.aspx?from=bottomrelated&id=60472|Golden Kela Awards held in Capital, NDTV]{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/bollywood/news/2009/random-golden-kela-awards-130309.html |title=Golden Kela Award goes to... - Oneindia Entertainment |publisher=Entertainment.oneindia.in |date=2009-03-13 |accessdate=2013-01-06}} The fifth award ceremony was held on 30 March 2013.http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Bollywood/Vicky-Donor-GOW-to-get-Anit-Kela-at-Golden-Kela-Awards/Article1-1015198.aspx{{cite news|title=Guess who’s nominated for Bollywood’s Golden Kela Awards?|publisher=Times Of India|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-12-22/news-interviews/35968919_1_rowdy-rathore-khiladi-housefull|accessdate=2012-12-24}} [[Jaspal Bhatti]] made a special appearance at the inaugural event, dishonoring the Indian film talent of the year 2008.{{cite web|title=Going bananas: Golden Kela Awards held in Capital|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/videos/87162/going-bananas-golden-kela-awards-held-in-capital.html|work=IBN Live}}{{cite news|title=हिमेश और प्रियंका को मिला केला अवॉर्ड|url=http://navbharattimes.indiatimes.com/articleshow/4243495.cms|newspaper=Navbharat Times|language=Hindi}} The intention behind the Golden Kela is to ridicule the Hindi film stars and acknowledge the worst of [[Indian Cinema]].{{cite news|author=ET Bureau |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-12-31/news/30576738_1_mausam-hollywood-razzies-lajja-award |title=Golden Kela Awards: Here’s a list of the contenders - Economic Times |publisher=Articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com |date=2011-12-31 |accessdate=2013-01-06}} Since, several award ceremonies each year celebrate the best of Hindi Cinema, ''Random Magazine'' and the Sundaas Film Institute chose to be different by giving away the Best of the Worst of Indian Cinema.{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/movies/jthj-dabangg-2-up-for-worst-film-at-golden-kela-awards_124891.htm |title=`JTHJ`, `Dabangg 2` up for worst film at Golden Kela Awards |publisher=Zeenews.india.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-06}}{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/imran-khan-anushka-sharma-nominated-for-golden-kela-awards/311789-8-66.html |title=Imran Khan, Anushka Sharma nominated for Golden Kela awards- Bollywood- IBNLive |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date=2012-12-22 |accessdate=2013-01-06}}{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/jthj-and-dabangg-2-up-for-worst-film-at-golden-kela-awards/1/239023.html |title=JTHJ, Dabangg 2 up for worst film at Golden Kela Awards : Bollywood, News - India Today |publisher=Indiatoday.intoday.in |date=2012-12-22 |accessdate=2013-01-06}} Golden Kela Awards are not meant to insult anyone. It is just a way to make it a laughter exercise, a therapy of sorts to forget about the failures and look at what went wrong with the movie and the act. [[Abhishek Bachchan]] came to the Golden Kela Awards in 2010 and accepted the Dara Singh Award for his attempt to speak with an American accent in Delhi 6{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Bollywood/Golden-Kela-Awards-not-meant-to-insult-anyone-Cyrus/Article1-667157.aspx |title=Golden Kela Awards not meant to insult anyone: Cyrus |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2013-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230201718/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Bollywood/Golden-Kela-Awards-not-meant-to-insult-anyone-Cyrus/Article1-667157.aspx |archivedate=2011-12-30 |df= }} == Categories == ===Main awards=== * Worst Movie * Worst Director * Worst Actor (Male) * Worst Actor (Female) * Worst Actor (Others) * Worst Supporting Actor (Male) * Worst Supporting Actor (Female) * Worst Debutant * Baawra Ho Gaya Hai Ke Award (literally, "Have you gone mad?") * Most Irritating Song * Most Atrocious Lyrics ===Special categories=== * Worst Pair * Lajja Award for Worst Treatment of a Serious Issue * [[Dara Singh]] Award For Worst Accent * Black Award for Emotional Blackmail * Insensitivity Award * Bas Kijiye Bahut Ho Gaya Award (literally, "Stop it, enough!") == Winners == ===2009=== Winners List: *Most Atrocious Lyrics: [[Anvita Dutt Guptan]] for Lucky Boy from [[Bachna Ae Haseeno]] *Most Unoriginal Story: [[Hari Puttar: A Comedy of Terrors]] *Most Irritating Song of the Year: Tandoori Nights from [[Karzzzz]] {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#b0c4de; text-align:center;" ! [[Diana Penty]] | ''[[Cocktail (2012 film)|Cocktail]]'' | {{nom}} |- | [[Farah Khan]] | ''[[Shirin Farhad Ki Toh Nikal Padi]]'' |rowspan="1"{{nom}} |- | [[Alia Bhatt]] | ''[[Student of the Year]]'' | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="5" | '''Worst Film''' | [[Son Of Sardar]] | ''For being offensive...not just to the Sikh community, but to anyone with intelligence and a sense of humour.'' | {{nom}} |- | [[Housefull 2]] | ''For being way more full (of bad jokes, poor acting, horrible writing and cast members) than we could take.'' | {{nom}} |- | [[Joker (2012 film)|Joker]] | ''For being one of the worst films ever made...anywhere.'' | rowspan="1" {{won}} |- | [[Khiladi 786]] | ''For (among other reasons) being written by the 'multi-talented genius' known as [[Himesh Reshammiya]]'' | {{nom}} |- | [[Dabangg 2]] | ''For not being [[Dabangg]]'' | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="5" |'''Most Irritating Song''' | Chinta ta Chita Chita | ''[[Rowdy Rathore]]'' | rowspan="1" {{won}} |- | Son Of Sardar | ''[[Son Of Sardar]]'' | {{nom}} |- | Anarkali Disco Chali | ''[[Housefull 2]]'' | {{nom}} |- | Disco Deewane | ''[[Student of the Year]]'' | {{nom}} |- | Hookah Bar | ''[[Khiladi 786]]'' | {{nom}} |} ;;Most Atrocious Lyrics *Anvita Dutt: Ishq wala Love (Student of the Year) *Amitabh Bhattacharya: Halkat Jawani (Heroine) *Shabbir Ahmed: Bipasha Bipasha (Jodi Breakers) *Shabbir Ahmed: Po Po (Son Of Sardar) *Sameer Anjaan: Chinta Ta Chita Chita (Rowdy Rathore) *Himesh Reshammiya: Hookah Bar (Khiladi 786) ;;Baawra Ho Gaya Hai Ke Award * Homi Adjania: For following up Being Cyrus with Cocktail. We had expectations from you, Homi. * Sanjay Khanduri: For taking his own awesome Ek Chaalis Ki Last Local, setting it in Delhi and making Kismat Love Paisa Dilli... and doing a horrible job of it. * Ali Azmat: For sounding like a parody of his former self in the song Maula from Jism 2. * Indian Moviegoers: For spending more than 600 crores on Bol Bachchan, Housefull 2, Agneepath, Rowdy Rathore and Ek Tha Tiger (we'll keep adding the crores as figures keep coming in for Khiladi 786 and Dabangg 2). ====Anti-Kela Awards (2012)==== * '''[[Paan Singh Tomar (film)|Paan Singh Tomar]]''' - ''For reminding us why we always (secretly) loved the dacoits more than the heroes.'' *'''[[Gangs of Wasseypur – Part 1|Gangs of Wasseypur]]''' - ''For reminding us that s***a Hindustan mein jab tak cinema hai, log bante rahenge.'' *'''[[Kahaani]]''' - ''For showing that a film doesn't need a 'hero' to be a hit.'' *'''[[Vicky Donor]]''' - ''For showing that you can make a 'family comedy' about sperm donation (and reminding us why we used to like [[Annu Kapoor]])'' ===2014=== '''Worst Actor (male)''' - ''[[Ajay Devgan]]'' for ''[[Himmatwala (2013 film)|Himmatwala]]'' '''Worst Actor (female)'''- ''[[Sonakshi Sinha]]'' for ''Everything She Did'' '''Worst director''' - ''[[Sanjay Leela Bhansali]]'' for [[Goliyon Ki Raasleela Ram-Leela]] '''Worst film''' - ''[[Himmatwala (2013 film)|Himmatwala]]'' '''Supporting Actor (Male)''' - [[Aditya Roy Kapur]] for [[Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani]] '''Supporting Actor (Female)''' - [[Deepika Padukone]], [[Jacqueline Fernandez]] and [[Ameesha Patel]] for [[Race 2]] '''Most Annoying Song''' - ''Party All Night'' from [[Boss (2013 Hindi film)|Boss]] '''Most Atrocious Lyrics''' - [[Sameer Anjaan|Sameer]] for ''Raghupati Raghav'' ([[Krrish 3]]) '''Most Pointless Sequel/Remake Award''' – ''[[Himmatwala (2013 film)|Himmatwala]]'' '''Why Are You Still Trying Award''' – ''[[Shahid Kapoor]]'' for [[R... Rajkumar]] '''Baawra Ho Gaya Hai Ke Award''' - ''[[Aamir Khan]]'' for [[Dhoom 3]] '''Worst Debut of the Year''' - [[Leander Paes]] for [[Rajdhani Express (film)]] ===Anti-Kela Awards=== *[[Go Goa Gone]] *[[Saheb, Biwi Aur Gangster Returns]] *[[The Lunchbox]] ===2015=== Worst Actor (male) - [[Arjun Kapoor]] for [[Tevar]] Worst Actor (female)- [[Sonam Kapoor]] for [[Prem Ratan Dhan Payo]] Worst director - [[Sooraj Barjatya]] for [[Prem Ratan Dhan Payo]] Worst film - [[Prem Ratan Dhan Payo]] (2015 film)|Prem Ratan Dhan Payo]] Most Annoying Song - [[Prem Ratan Dhan Payo]] (Title Track) Most Atrocious Lyrics - [[Alfaaz]] for Birthday Bash from [[Dilliwali Zaalim Girlfriend]] Most Pointless Sequel/Remake Award – [[MSG-2 The Messenger]] Why Are You Still Trying Award – [[Imran Khan (Bollywood actor)|Imran Khan]] Manoj Kumar Award for Historical "Accuracy" – [[Bajirao Mastani]] Dara Singh Award for Worst Accent - [[Randeep Hooda]] for [[Main Aur Charles]] Sangh Parivaar Award – [[Gerua]] from [[Dilwale (2015 film)|Dilwale]] Shakti Kapoor Award for Misogyny – [[Pyaar Ka Punchnama 2]] Bas Kijiye Bahut Ho Gaya Award – [[Sooraj Barjatya]] What The Hell Award – [[Sonakshi Sinha]] Baawra Ho Gaya Hai Ke Award – [[Vikas Bahl]] for [[Shaandaar]] ==See also== *[[Golden Raspberry Awards]] *[[Ghanta Awards]] *[[Filmfail Awards]] *[[Pigasus Award]] *[[Darwin Award]] *[[Random Magazine]] *[[Youth Film Handbook]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.goldenkela.com/ Golden Kela Official Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101124012427/http://randommagazine.in/ ''Random Magazine'' Official Website] *[https://www.youtube.com/user/randomxmag ''Random Magazine'' Official Youtube Channel] *[https://www.facebook.com/GoldenKelas Official Facebook Page] *[https://twitter.com/goldenkela Official Twitter Page] [[Category:Bollywood film awards]] [[Category:Ironic and humorous awards]]

revision.comment: removed "Tips for running group-dynamic games" section (Wikipedia is not for "how-to" content); removed "External links" section (both links appeared to be spammy/inappropriate for Wikipedia)
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=March 2008}} A '''group-dynamic game''' is an [[experiential education]] exercise that helps people to learn about themselves, [[Personal relationship|interpersonal relationships]], and how [[group (sociology)|groups]] function from a [[group dynamics]] or [[social psychology|social psychological]] point of view.
Group dynamics can be understood as complex from an interpersonal relationships point of view because it involves: * relationships between two people * relationships between a person and a group * relationships between groups
Group-dynamic [[game]]s are usually designed for the specific purpose of furthering [[personal development]], character building,<!--linked to [[character development]], which is a disambig page--> and [[teamwork]] via a group-dynamic [[Social environment|milieu]]. The group leader may sometimes also be the game leader, or between peers, the leadership and game-rules can change.
Some games require large spaces, special objects and tools, quietness or many before-game and after-game needs. When aged, frail or disabled people ("special needs") are involved, existing games may need modification to be used.
The use of group dynamic activities has a history of application in [[conflict resolution]], [[anger management]] and [[team building]] and many other areas such as [[drug rehabilitation]] and [[drama therapy]].
==Types== {{Prose|section|date=January 2017}} *[[Dramaturgy (sociology)]] *Adventure-based activities (or initiative tasks) *[[Icebreaker (facilitation)|Ice-breaker games]] *[[Large group game]]s *[[Psycho-drama]] *[[Role-playing game]]s *[[Team building]] games *[[Trust Fall|Trust-building game]]s *[[Win-win game]]s (also known as "cooperative games")
==Group problem solving activities== There are a number of exercises that propose a problem that the group must solve. Some of these simply benefit from the diversity of perspectives and background knowledge inherent in groups to find the answer more quickly (Trivia, Wuzzles) while another approach is to give each individual some information and the collective information is needed to solve the problem or challenge.
These can be simple or truly elegant situations. Many can be found for free on various websites and in books designed for use by trainers. Many are readily adaptable to different situations and desired outcomes.
==See also== *[[Alternative education]] *[[Training]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Group-dynamic game}} [[Category:Game terminology]] [[Category:Systems psychology]]

A '''hype man''', in [[hip hop music]] and [[rapping]], is a backup rapper and/or singer who supports the primary rappers with exclamations and interjections and who attempts to increase the audience's excitement with call-and-response chants.<ref name=Hilltop>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehilltoponline.com/life-style/the-role-of-the-hype-man-in-hip-hop-1.464291 |title=The Hilltop - The Role of The 'Hype Man' In Hip-Hop |publisher=Thehilltoponline.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717003938/http://www.thehilltoponline.com/life-style/the-role-of-the-hype-man-in-hip-hop-1.464291 |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>Barrett, Grant, 2006, ''The Official Dictionary of Unofficial English'', McGraw-Hill Professional, p. 182.</ref><ref>Hip Hop: An Encyclopedia of the Movement, Music, and Culture, Greenwood Publishing Group, p. 176.</ref><ref>Edwards, Paul, 2009, How to Rap: The Art & Science of the Hip-Hop MC, Chicago Review Press, p. 304.</ref><ref>"Kool Moe Dee". Thafoundation.com. Retrieved 2010-08-12.</ref><ref>"Record Executives Thought Jay-Z Was No Good » MTV Newsroom". Newsroom.mtv.com. 2009-08-26. Retrieved 2010-08-12.</ref> Music writer Mickey Hess expands the term as follows: "a hype man is a figure who plays a central but supporting role within a group, making his own interventions, generally aimed at hyping up the crowd while also drawing attention to the words of the [[Master_of_ceremonies#Hip_hop|MC]]".<ref name=IconsofHipHop>Hess, Mickey, 2007, ''Icons of Hip Hop: An Encyclopedia of the Movement, Music, and Culture'', Greenwood Publishing Group, p. 176.</ref>
Discussing the role of the hype man in the book ''[[How to Rap]]'', [[Royce da 5'9"]] describes how a hype man can contribute to a live performance: "a lot of my verses [can] be so constant with the flow [that] I'd need somebody to help me."<ref name="autogenerated304">Edwards, Paul, 2009, ''[[How to Rap]]: The Art & Science of the Hip-Hop MC'', Chicago Review Press, p. 304.</ref> [[Lateef the Truthspeaker|Lateef]] has stated, "You're gonna have to have somebody say something somewhere to give you a breath... usually it's just a matter of getting somebody to hit some line or some word in a line—that's all you really need."<ref name="autogenerated304"/>
==Origins== Early [[hip hop]] hype men included Cowboy and Creole of [[Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five]].<ref name= Hilltop/><ref name=IconsofHipHop/> [[Kool Moe Dee]] calls Creole “the original hype man”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thafoundation.com/moedee.htm |title=Kool Moe Dee |publisher=Thafoundation.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref> [[File:Public Enemy 4.jpg|thumb|right|American rapper [[Flavor Flav]] hyping up a crowd in May 2008]] The quintessential hype man, for many fans and musicians of the era, was [[Public Enemy (group)|Public Enemy]]'s hype man [[Flavor Flav]], whose exuberant approach to the art in the group's recordings and videos made him, arguably, the first household-name hype man, a figure more famous than many MCs. He established many of the conventions of the craft, such as an outlandish sense of style (epitomized by his wearing of large clocks around his neck) and a vocal style that contrasted dramatically with that of the MC (his rasping high voice was a counterpoint to [[Chuck D]]'s booming baritone). [[File:Hype-Man Relione with Chef Sean .jpg|thumb|right|Hype man Relione (right) performing with rapper Chef Sean]] [[Jay-Z]] began his career as a hype man for [[Jaz-O]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2009/08/26/jay-z-record-executives/ |title=Record Executives Thought Jay-Z Was No Good » MTV Newsroom |publisher=Newsroom.mtv.com |date=2009-08-26 |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref><ref>Vibe magazine, Jan 2004, Vol. 12, No. 1, published by Vibe Media Group, p. 75.</ref> and was later the hype man for [[Big Daddy Kane]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Jonathan Cunningham |url=http://www.browardpalmbeach.com/2007-03-15/music/kane-s-domain |title=Kane's Domain - Page 1 - Music - Broward/Palm Beach - Broward-Palm Beach New Times |publisher=Broward/Palm Beach |date=2007-03-15 |accessdate=2010-08-12}}</ref>
==Examples==<!-- DO NOT ADD MORE WITHOUT RELIABLE CITATIONS -->
Examples of hype men include [[Freaky Tah]] of the [[The Lost Boyz|Lost Boyz]], [[Memphis Bleek]] for [[Jay-Z]], and [[Proof (rapper)|Proof]] and [[Mr. Porter]] of [[D12]] for [[Eminem]].<ref name="IconsofHipHop" /> ''Icons of Hip Hop'' also notes that some producers, such as [[Sean Combs|Diddy]], [[Lil Jon]], [[Swizz Beatz]], and [[Jermaine Dupri]], "have transitioned from a hype man role to become [[rapper]]s and stars in their own right".<ref name="IconsofHipHop" />
Occasionally pop groups include a member up front alongside the lead singer who may perform backup vocals or percussion but largely functions to excite the audience through dancing and/or stage patter. Examples include [[Bob Nastanovich]] for [[Pavement (band)|Pavement]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grantland.com/features/indie-rock-legend-bob-nastanovich-pavement-silver-jews-horse-racing/|title='It Hasn't Been a Disaster: Indie-rock legend Bob Nastanovich on Pavement, the Silver Jews, and horse racing. But not in that order.|date=2012-06-20|author=Alex Pappademas|accessdate=2017-01-22}}</ref> and [[Guy Picciotto]] for [[Fugazi]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Nathan Leigh |url=http://afropunk.com/2011/05/public-enemy-the-forgotten-innovators-of-post-hardcore/ |title=Public Enemy: The Forgotten Innovators of Post-Hardcore |date=2011-05-18 |accessdate=2017-01-09}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Zasuul]], a kind of hype man in Mongolian wrestling
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hype Man}} [[Category:Entertainment]] [[Category:Hip hop]]
