revision.text:
{{redirect|Love film|the UK-based video service|LoveFilm}} {{for|films entitled "Romance"|Romance (disambiguation)#Film and theater{{!}}Romance (disambiguation)}} [[File:Tyrone power alice faye ragtime6.jpg|thumb|270px|[[Tyrone Power]] passionately, lovingly, embraces [[Alice Faye]] in the [[1938 in film|1938 film]] ''[[Alexander's Ragtime Band (film)|Alexander's Ragtime Band]]''.]] '''Romance films''' or '''romance movies''' are romantic love stories recorded in visual media for broadcast in theaters and on [[television|TV]] that focus on [[passion (emotion)|passion]], [[emotion]], and the affectionate romantic involvement of the main characters and the journey that their genuinely strong, true and pure romantic love takes them through dating, courtship or [[marriage]]. Romance films make the romantic love story or the search for strong and pure love and romance the main plot focus. Occasionally, romance lovers face obstacles such as [[finance]]s, physical [[illness]], various forms of [[discrimination]], psychological restraints or family that threaten to break their union of love. As in all quite strong, deep, and close romantic relationships, tensions of day-to-day life, [[temptation]]s (of [[infidelity]]), and differences in compatibility enter into the plots of romantic films.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.filmsite.org/romancefilms.html |title=Romance films |website=[[Filmsite.org]] |access-date=10 November 2016}}</ref>
Romantic films often explore the essential themes of [[love at first sight]], young with older love, unrequited romantic love, obsessive love, sentimental love, [[Spirituality|spiritual love]], forbidden love/romance, platonic love, sexual and passionate love, sacrificial love, explosive and destructive love, and [[Tragedy|tragic love]]. Romantic films serve as great escapes and fantasies for viewers, especially if the two people finally overcome their difficulties, declare their love, and experience life "happily ever after", implied by a reunion and final kiss. In romantic television series, the development of such romantic relationships may play out over many episodes, and different characters may become intertwined in different romantic arcs.
==Subgenres== * '''[[Historical romance]]''' – A romantic story with a period setting. This includes films such as ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' and ''[[Doctor Zhivago (film)|Doctor Zhivago]]''. * {{anchor|Romantic drama}}'''Romantic dramas''' usually revolve around an obstacle which prevents deep and true romantic love between two people. Music is often employed to indicate the emotional mood, creating an atmosphere of greater insulation for the couple. The conclusion of a romantic drama typically does not indicate whether a final romantic union between the two main characters will occur. Some examples of romantic drama films are ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'', ''[[The Bridges of Madison County (film)|The Bridges of Madison County]]'', ''[[The English Patient (film)|The English Patient]]'', ''[[Sommersby]]'', ''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'', ''[[Coming Home (1978 film)|Coming Home]]'', ''[[Jungle Fever]]'', ''[[Memoirs of a Geisha (film)|Memoirs of a Geisha]]'', ''[[Last Tango in Paris]]'', ''[[Water for Elephants (film)|Water for Elephants]]'', ''[[5 Centimeters per Second]]'', ''[[Love Story (1970 film)|Love Story]]'', and ''[[The Fault in Our Stars (film)|The Fault in Our Stars]]''.<ref>{{citation | first1=Wheeler W. | last1=Dixon | year=2000 | title=Film genre 2000: new critical essays | series=The SUNY series, cultural studies in cinema/video | page=238 | publisher=SUNY Press | isbn=0-7914-4514-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dgzACTHIAcsC&pg=PA238}}</ref> * '''[[Chick flick]]''' is a term often associated with romance films as many are targeted to a female audience.<ref>{{Cite book |editor-last=Simpson |editor-first=John |title=Oxford English Dictionary, 2nd edition, on CD-ROM Version 4.0 |location=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-19-956383-8}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |editor1-last=Stevenson |editor1-first=Angus |editor2-last= Lindberg |editor2-first=Christine A. |year=2010 |title=New Oxford American Dictionary, Third Edition |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=300 |isbn=978-0-19-539288-3}}</ref> Although many romance films may be targeted at women, this is not a defining characteristic of a romance film and a ''chick flick'' does not necessarily have a romance as a central theme, revolve around the romantic involvement of characters or even contain a romantic relationship. As such, the terms cannot be used interchangeably. Films of this genre include ''[[Dirty Dancing]]'', ''[[The Notebook (2004 film)|The Notebook]]'', ''[[Dear John (2010 film)|Dear John]]'', ''[[A Walk to Remember]]'', and ''[[Romeo + Juliet]]''. * '''[[Romantic comedy|Romantic comedies]]''' are films with light-hearted, humorous plotlines, centered on romantic ideals such as that true love is able to surmount most obstacles. Humour in such films tends to be of a verbal, low-key variety or situational, as opposed to slapstick.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/subgenre/romantic-comedy-d529 |title=Romantic Comedy |publisher=[[AllRovi]] |access-date=10 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811071237/http://www.allrovi.com/movies/subgenre/romantic-comedy-d529 |archivedate=11 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> Films within this genre include ''[[Four Weddings and a Funeral]]'', ''[[Love Actually]]'', ''[[Moonstruck]]'', ''[[As Good as It Gets]]'', ''[[Something's Gotta Give (film)|Something's Gotta Give]]'', ''[[It Happened One Night]]'', ''[[When Harry Met Sally...]]'', ''[[Annie Hall]]'', and ''[[The Apartment]]''. * '''[[Romantic fantasy|Romantic fantasies]]''' describe [[fantasy]] stories using many of the elements and conventions of the romance genre.<ref name="Robinson">{{cite web | url=http://web.utk.edu/~wrobinso/590_lec_fan.html| title=A Few Thoughts on the Fantasy Genre| author=William C. Robinson| accessdate=18 January 2009| date=October 2004 | publisher=University of Tennessee, Knoxville}}</ref> * {{anchor|Romantic action comedies}}'''Romantic action''' is a film that blend [[Romance (love)|romance]] and [[action film|action]]. Examples include ''[[Killers (2010 film)|Killers]]'', ''[[Knight and Day]]'', ''[[Mr. & Mrs. Smith (2005 film)|Mr. & Mrs. Smith]]'', ''[[This Means War (film)|This Means War]]'' and ''[[The Bounty Hunter (2010 film)|The Bounty Hunter]]''. * '''[[Romantic thriller]]''' is a genre of film which has a storyline combining elements of the romance film and the [[Thriller film|thriller genre]]. Some examples of romantic thriller films are ''[[The Adjustment Bureau]]'', ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (2004 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'', ''[[The Tourist (2010 film)|The Tourist]]'', ''[[The Bodyguard (1992 film)|The Bodyguard]]'', ''[[Unfaithful (2002 film)|Unfaithful]]'', and ''[[Wicker Park (film)|Wicker Park]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/wicker-park-v286560 |title=Wicker Park (2004) |publisher=AllRovi |access-date=10 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111027223231/http://www.allrovi.com/movies/movie/wicker-park-v286560 |archivedate=27 October 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of romance films]] * [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Passions]] * [[Romantic comedy]] * [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] * [[List of interracial romance films|Interracial romance film]] * [[Romance novel]] * [[Romance (love)]] * [[Romance (love)|True love]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.imdb.com/Sections/Genres/Romance/ IMDb guide to Romance movies] * [http://protista.org/greatest-romance-movies/ List of amazing romance movies] * [http://movies.romanticbug.com/ Romantic Movies Database] * [https://stylewhack.com/best-romantic-movies/ Best Romantic Movies]

{{For|other people with similar names|Stephen Paul (disambiguation){{!}}Stephen Paul}} {{Infobox person | name = Steve Paul | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Steve Paul | birth_date = {{Birth date |1941|04|28}} | birth_place = [[Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|10|21|1941|04|28}} | death_place = [[New York City]], United States | other_names = | occupation = Manager in the Entertainment Industry | known_for = being the manager of Johnny Winter and the owner of The Scene, a popular New York City Club in the 1960s and 1970s. He was also the founder of Blue Sky Records }} '''Steve Paul''' (born Stephen Neal Paul on April 28, 1941, Bronx, New York; died October 21, 2012, New York City) was the American one-time manager of [[Johnny Winter]], among other related performers, as well as being the owner of [[The Scene (performance venue)|The Scene]], a popular [[New York City]] club in the 1960s and 1970, and the founder of [[Blue Sky Records]].
==History== Paul's initial reputation was as the owner of 'Steve Paul's The Scene', a popular New York City club in the 1960s and 1970s. In 1968, he became the manager of Johnny Winter. Paul had travelled from New York to Texas to successfully promote his managerial abilities to Winter, after reading a ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' review of Texas music by [[Larry Sepulvado]], in which Winter was described as "the hottest item outside of [[Janis Joplin]]".<ref name = gibsonart>{{cite web|url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/40-years-of-johnny-winter-422/ |title=40 Years of Johnny Winter |publisher=Gibson.com |date=2009-04-22 |accessdate=2014-07-17}}</ref> Based on Paul's negotiating abilities, Winter shortly thereafter in 1968 signed the then-largest recording contract ever offered by [[Columbia Records]]: $600,000, payable over five years.<ref name = gibsonart/>
Winter performed regularly at Steve Paul's New York club, The Scene, where various artists, such as [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Jim Morrison]] and [[Janis Joplin]], would make guest appearances.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.classicbands.com/JohnnyWinterInterview.html |title=Interview With Johnny Winter |publisher=Classicbands.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-17}}</ref> Many of these performances were of historic significance, such as the performance by Jimi Hendrix, [[Buddy Miles]] and Johnny Winter in February 1969.<ref>[http://theselvedgeyard.wordpress.com/2010/04/13/winter-whites-johnny-edgar-legendary-winter-brothers/ Performance image and caption]. Winter Whites|Johnny and Edgar: Legendary Winter Brothers. Retrieved 2011-02-05</ref> It is also the place where on March 18, 1968 Jimi Hendrix and a very intoxicated Jim Morrison accompanied by Buddy Miles were recorded together live, on Hendrix's own recording device, a recording which has become notoriously sought after by fans and collectors alike.
Johnny Winter appeared at [[Woodstock Festival|Woodstock Music Festival]], but his performance was not included in the film or initial soundtrack recordings, due to unresolved contractual issues between Steve Paul and the festival organizers, prior to Winter's performance.<ref>[http://www.vinylrecords.ch/winter/Timeline/winter_timeline_1969.html The Johnny Winter Story]; Johnny Winter Timeline 1969; The Johnny Winter Story. Retrieved 2011-02-06.</ref>
Steve Paul was Winter's manager for fifteen years.<ref name = Sullivan>Mary Lou Sullivan, [http://www.johnnywinterbook.com/--_managers Description of Steve Paul]. ''Raisin' Cain: The Wild and Raucous Story of Johnny Winter''; book publication website. Retrieved 2011-02-01.</ref> In 1970, Paul, who also managed [[The McCoys]], brought the artists together,<ref name = gibsonart/> resulting in Winter's successful ''[[Johnny Winter And]]'' (1970), including the hit "[[Rock and Roll, Hoochie Koo]]". The McCoys had first met Winter during their term as the resident house band at The Scene, commencing in 1969.<ref>[http://www.answers.com/topic/the-mccoys-rock-group Profile of The McCoys]. [[Gale (publisher)|Gale]] Musician Profiles, as reprinted at www.answers.com. Retrieved 2011-02-05.</ref>
In 1973, Paul started [[Blue Sky Records]], a label promoted and distributed by [[Columbia Records]]. Between 1973 and 1982, it became the principal recording label for [[Johnny Winter]], [[Edgar Winter]], [[Rick Derringer]] and [[David Johansen]], all of whom were managed by Paul. Through Johnny Winter's involvement as a producer, the label is also credited with reviving the later career of [[Muddy Waters]]. The label largely ceased operations with Winter's departure in 1983, which coincided with the termination of his management relationship with Steve Paul.
In later years, Paul developed Downtown TV, an online entertainment network.<ref name = Sullivan/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NBAQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KYwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4648%2C251472 Article about Steve Paul], from the July 19, 1967 issue of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' * [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/24/nyregion/steve-paul-owner-of-the-former-scene-nightclub-dies-at-71.html NY Times obituary]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Paul, Steve}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:people from the Bronx]] [[Category:Impresarios]] [[Category:American music managers]]

{{primary sources|date=November 2018}} {{Orphan|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Top Talent | image = | genre = [[Talent show]] | company = Seconds2Impact Media | distributor = Seconds2Impact Media | creator = C.J. Allen | executive_producer = C.J. Allen
Jinah Kim | presenter = Elliott Ashby (2013–) | judges = C.J. Allen (2013-)
[[:ko:브로닌 멀렌|Bronwyn Mullen]] (2013)
Punita Bajaj (2013-)
MC Lucid (2013-) | country = South Korea | language = English | num_seasons = 1 | website = http://www.toptalentkorea.com | website_title = Official website }} '''''Top Talent''''' (탑 탤런트) is a [[talent show]] competition for English speaking performers in [[South Korea]]. The competition features singers, dancers, magicians, comedians, rappers, beat-boxers and other performers age 12 and up competing for a cash prize and the opportunity to appear on stage at a festival and venues around Korea. The first competition was held over the course of three days in June and July 2013.Kerry, Paul. [http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20130521000570 "International panel seeks ‘Top Talent’"] ''[[The Korea Herald]]'', Seoul, 21 May 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. Among its significant features, '''''Top Talent''''' was the first talent competition in South Korea to provide amateur and professional English speaking performers with the opportunity to perform in a large scale talent search process with the winner ultimately being decided by an audience vote in the show's finale. The show incorporates many of the characteristics seen in popular [[reality television]] talent competitions such as [[America's Got Talent]] and [[The X Factor (U.S. TV series)|The X-Factor]]. The show was created by C.J. Allen and will be produced as a web-series by Seconds2Impact Media set for release in August 2013.Word from the ROK. [http://wftrok.com/2013/04/18/top-talent-korea-a-multi-cultural-all-english-performance-competition/ "TOP TALENT KOREA: A MULTI-CULTURAL ALL ENGLISH PERFORMANCE COMPETITION"] ''Word from the ROK'', Seoul, 18 April 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. == Selection Process == === Auditions === Acts audition in front of a panel of four judges and a live audience. Acts have 90 seconds to perform before being voted upon by the judges. If the act receives three votes or a unanimous vote from the judges, they move on to the call-back round. === Call-Backs === During the Call-Back round, acts must perform a new routine or song that they did not perform for their audition. After all of the acts have performed, the judges deliberate to determine the Top 12 acts that will perform at the finale. The judges choose eight acts together and also have a "judge's choice" act selected by each judge individually to make up the Top 12. === Judge's Choice === Aside from the eight acts that the judges choose together to be part of the Top 12 as part of the call-back round deliberation process, each judge also selected one act to be their "judge's choice". === Finale === In the finale, the Top 12 acts each have the opportunity to perform on a large theater stage in front of the judges and a live audience. Following the performances, the judges eliminate six acts to determine the Top 6 from which the audience will determine the winner. == Season Synopses == === Season 1 (2013) === In the winter of 2012, Seconds2Impact Media announced that it would be launching [[South Korea]]'s first all-English talent search competition with auditions taking place in June 2013. In spring 2013, the host and judges were announced with radio personality Elliott Ashby acting as MCTop Talent. [http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/05/elliott-ashby-to-host-top-talent/ "ELLIOTT ASHBY TO HOST TOP TALENT"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708145123/http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/05/elliott-ashby-to-host-top-talent/ |date=2013-07-08 }} ''Top Talent'', Seoul, 5 March 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. and television personality Bronwyn Mullen,Top Talent. [http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/11/bronwyn-first-judge-announcement/ "First Judge Announcement"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708005733/http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/11/bronwyn-first-judge-announcement/ |date=2013-07-08 }} ''Top Talent'', Seoul, 11 March 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. reality TV singing competition finalist Punita Bajaj,Top Talent. [http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/25/third-judge-announcement/ "Third Judge Announcement"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708145316/http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/25/third-judge-announcement/ |date=2013-07-08 }} ''Top Talent'', Seoul, 25 March 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. media entrepreneur and talent promoter C.J. AllenTouch Base in Seoul. [http://world.kbs.co.kr/english/program/program_seoulreport_detail.htm?No=4315 "Top Talent Korea judges, CJ Allen & Punita Bajaj"] ''KBS World Radio'', Seoul, 18 May 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. and Korea's first expat comedian [[Sam Hammington]] set to judge. Prior to auditions however, Hammington announced that he would not be able to fulfill his role as a judge due to prior commitments. Hammington was then replaced by drum and bass performer MC Lucid.Top Talent. [http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/06/03/new-fourth-judge-announcement/ "New Fourth Judge Announcement"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708154442/http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/06/03/new-fourth-judge-announcement/ |date=2013-07-08 }} ''Top Talent'', Seoul, 3 June 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. In May 2013, it was announced that auditions and call-backs would be held at the Seoul Global Culture & Tourism Center in [[Myeong-dong]], [[Seoul]] with the finale to take place at the [[Yongsan]] Art HallKerry, Paul. [http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20130702000687 "‘Top Talent’ audition event enters final stage"] ''[[The Korea Herald]]'', Seoul, 2 July 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. and all three parts of the competition would be filmed and later released as a web-series through Seconds2Impact Media. Acts that attended the auditions hailed from countries around the world including Canada, the United States, [[Singapore]], [[England]], [[Indonesia]], Australia, the [[Philippines]], [[South Korea]], [[France]], [[Pakistan]] and [[South Korea]]. From the auditions, the judges put through 34 acts to the call-back round which were then whittled down to a Top 12. Following performances by the Top 12 acts at the finale, the judging panel deliberated to decide which acts would make up the Top 6 and that would face the audience vote. The winner of season 1 was soul/R&B/gospel singer Sonya-Maria from [[Hawaii]] and the runner-up was juggler Mickael Bellemene - a [[France|French]] national living in [[Singapore]]. === Season 2 === Plans for season 2 of Top Talent have not yet been officially announced by Seconds2Impact Media; however, in a radio interview on July 1, 2013, executive producer and judge C.J. Allen alluded to a second season which might take place in fall 2013 in order to keep up with the momentum of season 1. Allen also said that if season 2 were to go ahead, he would return as one part of the yet to be announced judging panel. ==Series Overview== ===Season 1=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%; width:100%;" |- ! scope="col" | Season ! scope="col" | Start ! scope="col" | Finish ! scope="col" | Winner ! scope="col" | Runner-up ! scope="col" | Third place ! scope="col" | Top 6 ! scope="col" | Top 12 ! scope="col" | Host ! scope="col" | Judges |- ! scope="row" | One ! June 29, 2013 ! July 6, 2013 ! style="background:#FFE0E0;" | Sonya-Maria ! style="background:#CEF2E0;" | Mickael Bellemene ! style="background:#E0E8FF;" | Kite Flying Robot ! style="background:#FFE0E0;" | Sonya-Maria
Mickael Bellemene
Kite Flying Robot
Kyle & Tony

Mickael Bellemene
Kite Flying Robot
Kyle & Tony

Susie Baik
Steam Marvel
Alex Kaggwa
Negative Motion
Lux & Scotty Soul ! Elliott Ashby ! C.J. Allen
Bronwyn Mullen
Punita Bajaj
MC Lucid |- |} ==Host and Judges== In March 2013, ''Top Talent'' producers announced that media producer, voice actor and radio personality Elliott Ashby had signed on to host Top Talent.Top Talent. [http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/05/elliott-ashby-to-host-top-talent/ "ELLIOTT ASHBY TO HOST TOP TALENT"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708145123/http://toptalentkorea.com/2013/03/05/elliott-ashby-to-host-top-talent/ |date=2013-07-08 }} ''Top Talent'', Seoul, 5 March 2013. Retrieved on 10 July 2013. In the weeks that followed the announcement of Ashby as host, ''Top Talent'' began to reveal the names of the personalities that would form the four-person judging panel. South African native and Korean television personality Bronwyn Mullen was announced as the first judge set to the join followed by Canadian-born media entrepreneur and Seconds2Impact Media CEO C.J. Allen and Punita Bajaj, who had herself competed in a Korean reality television singing competition similar to [[American Idol]]. A midst heavy anticipation, ''Top Talent'' producers announced the fourth judge to be Sam Hammington - the first foreigner to have done comedian in the [[Korean language]] in Korea. Despite having done a large scale marketing campaign featuring the likenesses of all four judges, Hammington was forced to leave the panel as a result of a conflict with his filming schedule. Producers responded quickly by filling the vacant judge seat with Seoul based British drum and bass performer MC Lucid. Following the success of season 1, Allen said he would return to the judging panel for season 2 if it moves forward. Ashby, Lucid and Bajaj have also expressed interest in returning for a second season but have not been confirmed. ==Prize== ===Season 1=== The winner of season 1 of ''Top Talent'' received 1 million [[Korean won]] in cash and the opportunity to perform on a main sub-stage at the 13th annual [[Boryeong]] Mud Festival. == References == {{commons category|Top Talent (Korea)}} {{reflist}} [[Category:2013 South Korean television series debuts]] [[Category:2013 web series debuts]] [[Category:Talent shows]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2010}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_size = | image = Wing Bowl 2007 overview.jpg | image_size = 300px | alt = | caption = Wing Bowl XV | status = Inactive | genre = [[Competitive eating]] competition | date = Friday before the [[Super Bowl]] | begins = | ends = | frequency = Ended | venue = [[Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)|Wells Fargo Center]] | location = [[Philadelphia]] | coordinates = | country = United States | years_active = | first = January 29, 1993 | founders = [[Al Morganti]], [[Angelo Cataldi]] | last = February 2, 2018 | prev = | participants = | attendance = 20,000+ | capacity = | area = | budget = | activity = | leader_name = Commissioner - [[Jon Dorenbos]] | patron = | organised = | filing = | member = | sponsor = [[WTEL (AM)]] | website = {{URL|http://wingbowl.cbslocal.com/}} | people = Last champion - [[Molly Schuyler]] }} '''Wing Bowl''' was an annual eating contest founded in 1993 by [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] talk-radio hosts [[Angelo Cataldi]] and [[Al Morganti]]. The contest was first broadcast on [[WTEL (AM)|WIP]]. About 150 people attended Wing Bowl I (held in a hotel) in 1993 to see a competition between two contestants. The event pits [[competitive eater]]s in a [[Buffalo wing]] eating contest. The Wing Bowl is traditionally held on the Friday before the [[Super Bowl]]. The event, which began as a radio promotion, has grown to encompass television, the Internet, and a contest for women who are termed "the Wingettes." Since 2000, the event was held at Philadelphia's [[Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)|Wells Fargo Center]], where it is still broadcast live on 94-WIP-FM. There are currently no television deals to broadcast the event live; however, a replay is usually shown on [[WPSG|CW 57]], [[Comcast SportsNet]], or one of the other local stations within the following week. The Wing Bowl drew crowds of over 20,000. The final Wing Bowl, Wing Bowl XXVI was held on February 2, 2018 and the winner was [[Molly Schuyler]], who devoured a record 501 wings in a half hour. ==Background== Wing Bowl was the brainchild of WIP radio host Al Morganti, who came up with the idea when it became apparent the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] were not going to make the Super Bowl anytime soon. It is also suggested that Morganti was fed up with the Buffalo Bills going to the Super Bowl and not winning. The first Wing Bowl was held in the lobby of the [[Wyndham Hotels & Resorts|Wyndham]] Franklin Plaza Hotel in [[Center City, Philadelphia|Center City]]. Carmen Cordero walked away with the inaugural title, receiving a [[hibachi]] as his prize. Since then, media coverage has grown to the point where every one of the major Philadelphia television stations has covered the event. The [[WPVI-TV|ABC 6]], [[KYW-TV|CBS Channel 3]] and [[WTXF-TV|Fox 29]] affiliates all aired live reports from the event during their morning news. Features on the event have appeared in the ''[[Courier-Post]]'', ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' and ''[[Philadelphia Daily News|Daily News]]'' as well as a host of newspapers in the surrounding counties. The event has been featured on ESPN and the syndicated television shows ''[[Real TV]]'' and ''[[The Montel Williams Show]]''. Segments on Wing Bowl have appeared on TV newscasts in cities throughout the country. Several Wing Bowl contestants, including "El Wingador," competed in Fox's "[[Glutton Bowl]]" in the spring of 2002. The 2007 Wing Bowl was carried on [[Comcast Cable]]'s [[Video on demand|On Demand]] channel. Then [[Mayor of Philadelphia]] and future [[Governor of Pennsylvania]] [[Ed Rendell]] attended Wing Bowls II, III, IV and VI, where he presented the winner with a "[[Liberty Bell]]" trophy. Other celebrities who have appeared include retired heavyweight boxer [[Randall "Tex" Cobb]], former [[Philadelphia 76ers|76ers]] President [[Pat Croce]], former [[Philadelphia Phillies|Phillies]] manager [[Larry Bowa]], [[U.S. Senator]] [[Arlen Specter]], and others. Major-league [[Umpire (baseball)|umpire]] [[Eric Gregg]] served as the "Commissioner" of Wing Bowl from its second year until his death from a [[stroke]] on 5 June 2006. From December 2006 to 2013, [[Pat Croce]] was the second commissioner. [[Jon Dorenbos]] has been the third commissioner since 2014. ==Qualifications== (As per Wing Bowl Commissioner [[Jon Dorenbos]]) Entry into Wing Bowl can be gained in two ways, the first of which is successfully performing an "eating stunt" on air during ''The Morning Show'' at the 94 WIP studios in [[Center City, Philadelphia]], with Al Morganti as judge. Stunts have included eating 20 cups of cooked [[oatmeal]], eating {{convert|3.75|lb|kg}} of [[creamed spinach]] with {{convert|3.75|lb|kg}} of [[hot sauce]], and eating five [[Big Mac]]s. The stunt must be completed within a time limit negotiated between the contestant and Morganti. Morganti, known to be a tough judge, has disallowed stunts that involved what he considers "cheating", such as dipping bread into a beverage to make it easier to swallow, or breaking up a food item into constituent parts for easier chewing (such as separating hot dogs from their buns). He is also tough on contestants who suggest a stunt involving liquid consumption; ''The Morning Show'' hosts prefer eating stunts over drinking stunts. If a person offers to perform a drinking stunt, it must be compelling to the hosts, such as Wing Bowl XIV champion [[Joey Chestnut]]'s offer to drink {{convert|1|gal|l}} of [[milk]]. The hosts deemed it not difficult enough, but, fortunately for Chestnut, former champion Bill "El Wingador" Simmons was present and declared the stunt to have a high level of difficulty, upon which the hosts accepted his offer, with a five-minute time limit to complete the challenge. The other way to gain entry to Wing Bowl is to win a "Wingoff."[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20100108&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=1080801&Ref=PH "Wing Bowl Wingoff At PJ Whelihan's In Haddonfield"]. Portal to gallery of photographs (100) related to Wing Bowl. ''[[Courier-Post]]''. January 8, 2010. Accessed January 22, 2010. A "Wingoff"[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20090115&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=901150802&Ref=PH "2009 Wing Bowl: Wing-Off In S.J."]. Portal to gallery of photographs (45) related to Wing Bowl. ''Courier-Post''. January 15, 2009. Accessed January 22, 2010. is a 10-minute eating contest held at a Philadelphia or [[South Jersey]] bar hosted by former Philadelphia Eagle and WIP Host Hugh Douglas and WIP Personality Marc Farzetta. The "Wingoffs" began in 2005 when 610 WIP decided to spoof the [[Philadelphia Big 5|Big 5 Philadelphia]] area universities basketball teams. The winner of these "Wingoffs" gain automatic entry into the Wing Bowl. ==Cancellation== WIP announced on October 30, 2018 that event was being canceled after 26 years because the time for doing so felt right after the Eagles won [[Super Bowl LII]]. According to WIP program director Spike Eskin, "When Wing Bowl started ... a large part of it was the lead-up to the Super Bowl never involved the Eagles. We just wanted to get to the promised land."{{cite news|last=Berkery|first=Sheri|url=https://www.courierpostonline.com/story/news/local/south-jersey/2018/10/30/wing-bowl-wip-ends-competitive-eating-competition-philadelphia/1816859002/|title=WIP ends controversial Wing Bowl's long run in Philadelphia|date=October 30, 2018|newspaper=Courier-Post|access-date=November 8, 2018}}{{cite news|last=Bryan|first=Cleve|url=https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2018/10/30/94wip-ends-wing-bowl-after-26-years/|title=‘I Think It Ran Its Course’: 94WIP Ends Wing Bowl After 26 Years|date=October 30, 2018|work=[[CBS Philly]]|access-date=November 8, 2018}} == Champions == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Wing

Wings Eaten|last=Santoliquito|first=Joseph|date=January 31, 2014|department=Sports|website=CBS Philly|accessdate=July 8, 2015}} | 363 | Patrick Bertoletti | 356 |- | XXIII | January 30, 2015 | Patrick Shoudt]] |409 | rowspan=2|David T. "Wings & Things" Brunelli |386 |- |XXVI |February 2, 2018 |Molly Schuyler |501 |396 |} ==Past Wing Bowls== ===2007 - Wing Bowl XV=== Wing Bowl 15[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20090123&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=702020802&Ref=PH "Wing Bowl 2007"]. Portal to gallery of photographs (78) related to Wing Bowl. ''Courier-Post''. Jan. 23, 2007. Accessed January 22, 2010. is known as "Philadelphia Against The World". Tickets sold out on the first day of sales. Wing Bowl 15 was presented by [[Philadelphia Park Racetrack|Philadelphia Park Casino]]. [[Pat Croce]] was this year's Wing Bowl Commissioner. Pat took the helm after the tragic loss of WIP's dear friend [[Eric Gregg]].[http://www.610wip.com/pages/134695.php?contentType=4&contentId=248823 WIP - Philadelphia's Sports Radio - *] === 2008 - Wing Bowl XVI === Going into Wing Bowl 16[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20090126&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=802010809&Ref=PH "2008 Wing Bowl 16"]. Portal to gallery of photographs (38) related to Wing Bowl. ''Courier-Post''. Jan. 26, 2008. Accessed January 22, 2010. WIP Host, Angelo Cataldi, billed it as the greatest Wing Bowl ever. With El Wingador coming out of retirement to square off against the number one eater in the world, Joey Chestnut. Wing Bowl 16[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20090126&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=802010804&Ref=PH "2008- Wing Bowl 16 (Part 2)"]. Portal to gallery of photographs (50) related to Wing Bowl. ''Courier-Post''. Jan. 26, 2008. Accessed January 22, 2010. also featured a change in chicken wing providers, which contributed to the shattering of the elusive 200 wing mark. === 2009 - Wing Bowl XVII === Unlike the past years in which professional eaters were allowed to participate, Wing Bowl 17[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20090130&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=901300801&Ref=PH "Wing Bowl 17 Gallery 1"]. Portal to gallery of photographs (49) related to Wing Bowl. ''Courier-Post''. Jan. 30, 2009. Accessed January 22, 2010. on January 30, 2009 at the [[Wachovia Center]], was an all Amateur eater event, promoting eaters from the local neighborhoods in and around the Philadelphia area. There are 25 eaters in Wing Bowl 17,[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20090130&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=901300802&Ref=PH "Wing Bowl 17 Gallery 2"]. Portal to gallery of photographs (57) related to Wing Bowl. ''Courier-Post''. Jan. 30, 2009. Accessed January 22, 2010. with Wing Bowl 8 Champion "Tollman Joe" participating. This marks the first occasion that Wing Bowl creator [[Al Morganti]] gave a special dispensation that Tollman Joe did not have to perform an eating stunt to be in the Wing Bowl field, since he has been the only amateur to beat Bill "El Wingador" Simmons. Jonathan "Super" Squibb[http://www.courierpostonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Dato=20090126&Kategori=NEWS01&Lopenr=901260802&Ref=PH "2009 Wing Bowl: S.J. Contestants"]. Portal to gallery of photographs (10) related to Wing Bowl. ''Courier-Post''. Jan. 26, 2009. Accessed January 22, 2010. of Winslow Twp., NJ, took the Wing Bowl 17 title of Wing Bowl Champion by eating 203 wings. === 2010 - Wing Bowl XVIII === Wing Bowl 18 took place on February 5, 2010. Jonathan Squibb finished with a total of 238 wings to win his second Wing Bowl in a row. Squibb finished 93 wings ahead of the second place finisher and won a [[Ford F-Series#Twelfth generation (2009–2014)|Ford F-150]] truck and a championship ring as prizes.{{cite news|last=Hurdle|first=Jon|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-wingbowl-idUSTRE61442N20100205|title=Wing Bowl celebrates Philadelphia's raucous sports|date=February 5, 2010|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}{{cite news|last=White|first=Bil|url=http://articles.mcall.com/2010-02-06/news/all-bw_5wings-wing-bowl-bill-white.7170238feb06_1_wing-bowl-radio-station-wip-bucket-list|title=Wing Bowl checked off bucket list|date=February 6, 2010|newspaper=[[The Morning Call]]|accessdate=February 9, 2017}} === 2011 - Wing Bowl IXX === Jonathan Squibb won for the third consecutive year by 255 eating wings to win Wing Bowl 19. Squibb's total broke the record of 241 wings set by [[Joey Chestnut]] at Wing Bowl 16 (2008) and was one wing more than second place finisher Bill Simmons was able to eat. Squibb won $20,000 in cash and 2011 [[Ram Pickup#Fourth generation (2009–present; DS/DJ/D2)|Dodge Ram truck]].{{cite news|last=Santoliquito|first=Joseph|authorlink=Joseph Santoliquito|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2011/02/04/squibb-threepeats-as-wing-bowl-champion/|title=Squibb Threepeats As Wing Bowl Champion|date=February 4, 2011|website=[[WCAU]]|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Hurdle|first=Jon|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-food-competition-idUSTRE7134S420110204|title=Philly Wing Bowl produces new record, slim victory|date=February 4, 2011|agency=Reuters|accessdate=February 9, 2017}} === 2012 - Wing Bowl XX === [[Takeru Kobayashi]] set a new competition record by eating 337 wings to win Wing Bowl 20. Kobayashi's total was 82 wings more than the previous competition record set by Jonathan Squibb. Squibb also broke his own record, but finished in second with 271 wings. Kobayashi won $20,000 in cash and a championship ring as prizes.{{cite news|last=Davis|first=Phil|url=http://www.nj.com/gloucester-county/index.ssf/2012/02/wing_bowl_20_proves_historic_w.html|title=Wing Bowl XX proves historic with Kobayashi victory, end of El Wingador era|date=February 4, 2012|newspaper=[[South Jersey Times]]|via=[[NJ.com]]|accessdate=February 8, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Stamm|first=Dan|url=http://www.nbcphiladelphia.com/news/weird/Wing-Bowl-20-138631869.html|title=Wing Bowl 20: Kobayashi Eats Record 337 Wings|date=February 3, 2012|website=WCAU|accessdate=February 8, 2017}} === 2013 - Wing Bowl XXI === Wing Bowl 21 was won by James McDonald who ate a total of 287 wings. McDonald finished five wings ahead of three-time champion Jonathan Squibb to win $20,000 in cash and a $7,500 championship diamond ring.{{cite news|last=Green|first=Joe|url=http://www.nj.com/south/index.ssf/2013/02/beer_babes_and_buffalo_wings_a.html|title=Beer, babes and buffalo wings abound at Wing Bowl XXI|date=February 4, 2012|newspaper=South Jersey Times|via=NJ.com|accessdate=February 8, 2017}}{{cite news|last=Wisniewski|first=Mike|url=http://www.thedp.com/article/2013/02/jamie-the-bear-mcdonald-takes-wing-bowl-21-home-to-new-england|title=Skin, breasts 'n wings at WIP's Wing Bowl 21|date=February 3, 2013|newspaper=[[The Daily Pennsylvanian]]|accessdate=February 8, 2017}} === 2014 - Wing Bowl XXII === [[Molly Schuyler]] won Wing Bowl 22 by eating a total of 363 wings. Schuyler's total broke the previous record of 337 set at Wing Bowl 20 by Takeru Kobayashi. [[Patrick Bertoletti]] finished second with 356 wings.{{cite news|last=Santoliquito|first=Joseph|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2014/01/31/molly-schuyler-sets-a-record-wins-wing-bowl-22-with/|title=Molly Schuyler Sets A Record, Wins Wing Bowl 22 With 363 Wings Eaten|date=January 31, 2014|website=[[KYW-TV]]|accessdate=February 8, 2017}} Schuyler received the $22,000 top prize for her win.{{cite news|author=|first=|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/31/molly-schuyler-chicken-wings-record_n_4703954.html|title=Molly Schuyler Eats 363 Chicken Wings In 30 Minutes, Sets New Wing Bowl Record|date=January 31, 2014|website=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=February 8, 2017}} === 2015 - Wing Bowl XXIII === The winner of Wing Bowl 23 was Patrick Bertoletti. Bertoletti ate 444 wings to set a new Wing Bowl record and finished four wings ahead of defending champion Molly Schuyler.{{cite news|last=Santoliquito|first=Joseph|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2015/01/30/pat-bertoletti-upsets-molly-schuyler-to-win-wing-bowl-23/|title=Pat Bertoletti Upsets Molly Schuyler To Win Wing Bowl 23|date=January 30, 2015|website=KYW-TV|accessdate=February 8, 2017}} Bertoletti received a [[Harley-Davidson FLSTF Fat Boy|Harley Davidson Fat Boy]] motorcycle, $10,000 in cash, and a one-of-a-kind commemorative ring for winning.{{cite web|last=Adomaitis|first=Greg|url=http://www.nj.com/south/index.ssf/2015/01/wing_bowl_2015_winner_patrick_bertoletti_bests_mol.html|title=Wing Bowl 2015 winner Patrick Bertoletti bests Molly Schuyler with 444 to 440|date=January 30, 2015|website=NJ.com|accessdate=February 8, 2017}} === 2016 - Wing Bowl XXIV === Molly Schuyler won Wing Bowl 24 with a total of 429 wings to finish 21 wings ahead of second place finisher Patrick Bertoletti. Schuyler won a 2016 Harley Davidson Fat Boy motorcycle, $10,000 in cash, and a custom made Wing Bowl 24 championship ring as prizes.{{cite web|last=O'Neil|first=Erin|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2016/02/molly_schuyler_regains_wing_bowl_crown_after_downi.html|title=Molly Schuyler regains Wing Bowl crown after downing 429 wings|date=February 5, 2016|website=NJ.com|accessdate=February 8, 2016}} === 2017 - Wing Bowl XXV === [[Bob Shoudt|Bob "Notorious B.O.B." Shoudt]] won Wing Bowl 25 with a count of 409 wings to finish ahead of David T. "Wings & Things" Brunelli by 23 wings. Celebrity guests included actor/rapper, [[Coolio]] and former pro-wrestler, [[Ric Flair]]. Shoudt won $10,000 in cash, a [[Hyundai Santa Fe#Third generation (DM, NC, 2012–present)|Hyundai Santa Fe]], a ring and a medal as prizes.{{cite web|last=Everett|first=Rebecca|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2017/02/wing_bowl_25_notorious_bob_wins_it_all_for_eating.html|title=Wing Bowl 25: Notorious B.O.B. wins it all by eating 409 wings|date=February 3, 2017|website=NJ.com|accessdate=March 4, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Vadala|first1=Nick|last2=Tornoe|first2=Rob|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/real-time/Notorious-BOB-wins-Wing-Bowl-25-while-Wingette-of-the-Year-is-a-shocker.html|title=Notorious B.O.B. wins Wing Bowl 25, Wingette of the Year is a shocker|date=February 3, 2017|website=[[Philly.com]]|accessdate=March 4, 2017}} === 2018 - Wing Bowl XXVI === Molly Schuyler broke her own female record and devoured an event-record 501 wings to win the title. She received $5,000, a 2018 [[Hyundai Sonata]], a ring and medal. "Wings & Things" was 2nd, 105 behind her.{{cite web|last=Porter|first=Andrew|url=http://Philadelphia.CBSLocal.com/2018/02/02/Molly-Schuyler-Wing-Bowl-Champion|title=Molly Schuyler Sets Record By Eating 501 Wings To Win Wing Bowl XXVI|date=2018-02-02|website=Philadelphia.CBSLocal.com|accessdate=2018-02-04}} ==See also== *[[Competitive eating]] {{Portal|Philadelphia}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://wingbowl.cbslocal.com/ Official Wing Bowl 19 Website] * [http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/wingbowl/ Philly.com Coverage of Wing Bowl] * [http://www.phillysportsline.com/photo/wingbowl/wingbowl14/ Photos of the Virgin Wing Bowl can be viewed here on PhillySportsline.com] {{Competitive eating}} [[Category:Competitive eating]] [[Category:Culture of Philadelphia]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1993]] [[Category:Recurring events disestablished in 2018]] [[Category:Sports entertainment]] [[Category:Annual events in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:2018 disestablishments in Pennsylvania]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{Orphan|date=February 2015}}
{{Infobox dot-com company | company_type = Not-for-profit | name = YourView | logo = YourView logo.png | parent = | foundation = May 2012 | location_city = [[Melbourne]] | location_country = [[Australia]] | area_served = | owner = OurView Foundation | founder = [[Tim van Gelder]] | url = [http://www.yourview.org.au yourview.org.au] | website_type = [[Debate]], [[deliberative democracy]] | language = English | current_status = Inactive }}
'''YourView''' is an Australian [[nonprofit organization|not-for-profit]] [[debate]] website, founded in 2012.
Drawing upon the aims and principles of [[deliberative democracy]] theory, the website promotes considered debate in order to establish the "collective viewpoint" on political and social issues.<ref name="self-about">{{Cite web | title = About YourView | publisher = YourView Australia | url = http://yourview.org.au/page/about | accessdate = 27 September 2012}}</ref>
== Organisation == YourView is supported by the not-for-profit Ourview Foundation ([[Australian Company Number|ACN]] 154 763 970), established in 2011 by the Australian philosopher [[Tim Van Gelder]] in collaboration with the public intellectual Paul Monk. It is funded by voluntary donations.<ref name="self-about" />
The site was launched publicly in May 2012 and was maintained and developed by a staff of volunteers based in [[Melbourne]]. The website is currently inactive, and the project on hold.
== Content == YourView drew on ideas developed within the [[deliberative democracy]] movement, which promotes rational deliberation as a means of forming opinions and guiding policy decisions.<ref name="theage-1">{{Cite web | title = Full transcript: Tim van Gelder | publisher = The Age | url = http://www.theage.com.au/national/full-transcript-tim-van-gelder-20120313-1uxzr.html | last = Short | first = Michael | date = 14 March 2012 | accessdate = 27 September 2012}}</ref>
Users initially voted for or against a proposition based on a current issue, and were subsequently invited to post comments to justify their adopted stance. Each debate was prefaced by an "explainer", which provided basic information about the issue being discussed including an outline of key arguments.<ref name="crikey">{{Cite web | title = New Kid on the Block: YourView, a more considered taste taker | publisher = Crikey | url = http://www.crikey.com.au/2012/02/27/new-kid-on-the-block-yourview-a-more-considered-taste-taker/ | last = Simons | first = Margaret | date = 27 February 2012 | accessdate = 27 September 2012}}</ref>
As part of its objective to promote constructive and informed debate, YourView used an algorithm to assign each user a credibility score; the algorithm aimed to quantify a series of "[[epistemic virtues]]" that collectively determined the extent to which an individual user has contributed to the deliberative process. The raw "for-against" vote was weighted by user credibility scores to compute a "collective wisdom" metric,<ref name="crikey" /> thereby setting it apart from purely aggregative [[opinion poll]]ing.<ref name="theage-2">{{Cite web | title = The getting of wisdom | publisher = The Age | url = http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/society-and-culture/the-getting-of-wisdom-20120313-1uy8a.html | last = Short | first = Michael | date = 14 March 2012 | accessdate = 27 September 2012}}</ref> Details about which factors influence the algorithm were not published, which reduced the model's transparency but aimed to prevent users from [[gaming the system]].<ref name="heise">{{Cite web | title = Software bestraft Schwätzer | publisher = [[:de:Heise Online|Heise Online]] | url = http://www.heise.de/tr/artikel/Software-bestraft-Schwaetzer-1586112.html | last = Grötker | first = Ralf | language = German | date = 31 May 2012 | accessdate = 27 September 2012}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://yourview.org.au YourView] * [http://ourview.org.au Ourview Foundation]

{{Use Indian English|date=May 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox TV channel | launch = {{Launch date and age|df=y|1999|07|06}} | logofile = File:Zee News Logo.jpeg | logoalt = | owner =[[Zee Media Corporation Limited]] | headquarters =[[India]] | country = [[India]] | language = [[Hindi]] | network = [[Terrestrial television|Broadcast]] [[television]] and online | picture format = [[1080i]] [[HDTV]]
{{small|(downscaled to [[4:3]] [[576i]] for the [[SDTV]] feed)}} | broadcast area = Worldwide | sister names = [[Zee Business]]

[[Zee Salaam]] | terr serv 1 = [[Oqaab]]
(Afghanistan) | terr chan 1 = Channel 45 | sat serv 1 = [[Airtel digital TV]] | sat chan 1 = Channel 311 | sat serv 2 = [[Tata Sky]] | sat chan 2 = Channel 511 | sat serv 3 = [[Reliance Digital TV]] | sat chan 3 = Channel 408 | sat serv 4 = [[Dish TV]] | sat chan 4 = Channel 651 | sat serv 5 = [[Videocon d2h]] | sat chan 5 = Channel 307 | cable serv 1 = [[Siti Cable]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 303 | cable serv 2 = [[Cable TV Hong Kong]] | cable chan 2 = Channel 852 | cable serv 3 = [[Starhub TV]]
(Singapore) | cable chan 3 = Channel 158 | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | adsl serv 1 = [[Now TV (China)|now TV]]
(Hong Kong) | adsl chan 1 = Channel 785 | online serv 1 = Live Stream (International) | online chan 1 = [http://zeenews.india.com/live-tv live Web stream at Zee News] | name = Zee News | website = {{URL|http://www.india.com/}} | logocaption = | logosize =150px }} '''Zee News''' is an Indian news channel launched in 6 July 1999 and is the flagship property of [[Zee Media Corporation Limited]], company and a subsidiary of [[Essel Group]]. The channel is owned by [[Subhash Chandra]], an independent member of the [[Rajya Sabha]] .{{cite web | url=http://www.afaqs.com/news/story/38204_Zee-News-takes-punch-line | title=Zee News takes punch line | publisher=afaqs | work=afaqs news bureau | date=24 July 2013 | accessdate=19 December 2015}} == Controversies == === Jindal Group incident === The channel was tried for allegedly extorting [[Indian rupee|Rs]] 100 crore from the [[Jindal Group]]{{cite news|title=Jindal plays CD, claims Zee editors demanded Rs. 100 crore|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/jindal-plays-cd-claims-zee-editors-demanded-rs-100-crore/article4031340.ece|accessdate=4 December 2014|newspaper=The Hindu}} and two senior journalists [[Sudhir Chaudhary (journalist)]] and Sameer Ahluwalia{{Cite news|url=https://m.timesofindia.com/india/Two-Zee-editors-arrested-for-Rs-100-crore-extortion-bid/articleshow/17391903.cms|title=Two Zee editors arrested for 'Rs 100-crore extortion bid' - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-01-30}}were arrested.{{cite news|title=Naveen Jindal vs Zee: Senior journalists arrested over alleged extortion|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/naveen-jindal-vs-zee-senior-journalists-arrested-over-alleged-extortion-298095|accessdate=4 December 2014|publisher=NDTV India}}{{cite news|title=Jindal Group and Zee television in extortion scandal|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/jindal-group-and-zee-television-in-extortion-scandal/story-e6frg6so-1226527713986?nk=e835e32ddf2956600de185626015a1b1|accessdate=4 December 2014|publisher=The Australian}} [[Naveen Jindal]] accused Zee News of trying to extort Rs 100 crore from him for not airing stories against his company in [[Indian coal allocation scam|Coal Scam]]. Zee News refuted the charges and made counter charges of Jindal offering them Rs 25 crore to halt their investigations against [[Jindal Steel]] in the coal scam.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/Naveen-Jindal-accuses-Zee-News-of-extortion-channel-hits-back/articleshow/16956098.cms |title=Naveen Jindal accuses Zee News of extortion, channel hits back - The Times of India |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2012-10-25 |accessdate=2012-11-03}} Which is not yet sorted by both the parties by saying it a miscommunication. ===Allegations of fabrications=== {{main|2016 JNU sedition controversy}} ''Zee News'' reported that some of the students from Democratic Students' Union (DSU) raised slogans such as "''Bharat ki barbadi''" ("Destruction of India") and "''Pakistan Zindabad''" ("long live Pakistan"){{cite news |title = From 'Pakistan Zindabad' to 'Bharat ki barbaadi' - Slogans that were raised by 'anti-nationals' in JNU |url = http://zeenews.india.com/news/india/from-pakistan-zindabad-to-bharat-ki-barbaadi-slogans-that-were-raised-by-anti-nationals-in-jnu_1855562.html |newspaper = Zee News |date = 14 February 2016}}. In a letter Vishwa Deepak, who later resigned from the channel after expressing reservations over its 'biased coverage' alleged that "''Our biases made us hear "Bhartiya Court Zindabad" as ''Pakistan Zindabad''.'' ("long live Indian courts" as "long live Pakistan."). After Delhi police report it was claimed that footage was genuine.{{cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/zee-news-producer-quits-video-we-shot-had-no-pakistan-zindabad-slogan/ |title=Zee News producer quits: Video we shot had no Pakistan Zindabad slogan |date=22 February 2016 |newspaper=The Indian Express }} Sudhir Chaudhary, Zee News Editor, said "Our channel only showed what was happening there, whatever we have shown is 100% authentic."{{cite web | url = http://www.newslaundry.com/2016/02/21/we-speak-with-the-zee-news-journalist-who-resigned-over-the-channels-coverage-of-junrow/ | title = We speak with the Zee News journalist who resigned over the channel's coverage of #JNURow | newspaper = Newslaundry | date = 21 February 2016 }} Later the forensic report revealed that that footage was authentic and the slogans reported were never raised. ==See also== * [[Essel Group]] * [[Zee Entertainment Enterprises]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{official}} {{Essel Group}} {{Television news in India}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zee News}} [[Category:24-hour television news channels in India]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1999]] [[Category:Hindi-language television channels in India]] [[Category:Hindi-language television stations]] [[Category:Essel Group]] [[Category:Zee Entertainment Enterprises]] [[Category:Media companies of India]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of India]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} '''Zoran Bečić''' (April 2, 1939 – March 29, 2006) was one of the most prominent artists of the Bosnian theatrical community in the 20th century.
One of the founding actors of [[Sarajevo War Theatre]], he studied acting under the famous Belgrade Academy of Dramatic Arts' Professor Mate Milošević, graduating with the 1966 class. Bečić's professional acting career began in [[Dubrovnik]], but after two years, he joined Sarajevo's [[Malo pozorište]] (Little Theatre), the predecessor of today's [[Kamerni teatar 55]] (Chamber Theatre 55). He made his ''debut'' in the unforgettable performance in Radoslav Dorić's ''Noć ubica'' (The night of murderers).
Following several notable roles, in 1971 he decides to try his luck in Belgrade, but returns to [[Sarajevo's National Theatre]], two years later. For the next two decades, he continues his collaboration with [[Kamerni teatar 55]], earning three ''Zlatni lovorov vijenac'' (Golden Wreath of Laurel) Awards at the international theatre festival [[MESS]]. The last one, in 2004, was given to him for Life Achievement and Contribution to Performing Arts.
During the 1991-1995 [[Sarajevo siege]], Bečić participates in the first theatrical project that was to jump-start [[Sarajevo]]'s war production scene, the famous [[Sklonište]] (The Shelter), and directs another - [[Memoari Mine Hauzen]] (The Memoirs of Mina Hauzen).
Asked about his decision to stay in Sarajevo during the war, he said: "Many have asked me if I, a Serb from Čačak, ever regretted staying in Sarajevo for the duration of the war. Never. God forbid that it ever happens again, but I would do it all over again. With all the sadness, tragedy and horror that this city had been through, there was equally as much warmth, love, understanding and tender words."
Bečić's film and TV credits include appearances in TV series ''[[Viza za budućnost]]'' (2002), and ''Aleksa Santic'' (1990).
In March 2006, he made his first and last appearance alongside his daughter, actress [[Zorana Bečić]], in [[Safet Plakalo]]'s ''Lutkino bespuće'' (A Doll's Wasteland). He died two weeks later on the eve of the premiere of ''Rodoljupci'' at [[Sarajevo]]'s National Theatre, where he was the Director of Drama. Bečić was farewelled at [[Sarajevo]]'s Lav cemetery on the day he was to take to the stage in the role of Zhitov.
==Sources==
* ''A Word About Dr Kukrić'', ''Lutkino bespuće'', [[Sarajevo War Theatre (SARTR)]], 2005 *{{IMDb name|0065054}}
{{authority control}}
